node.title: `label_bquote()` not working with column facet

node.body:
`label_bquote()` has both `rows` and `cols` arguments! You'll need to specify which is which to get it working with `facet_grid()`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point()
p + facet_grid(vs ~ ., labeller = label_bquote(rows = 'yy'~.(vs)~'V'))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/BeCOr4C.png)

``` r
p + facet_grid(. ~ vs, labeller = label_bquote(cols = 'yy'~.(vs)~'V'))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/igQjuUc.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-17 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>
Thanks!!!

node.title: Replacing each .stroke by .pt?

node.body: These are internal constants you shouldn't be concerned with. `.stroke` is used for the width of the pch symbol stroke only which is why it isn't occurring any other place

node.title: [feature request] different lineend types at start and end of segment

node.body: That is unfortunately not technically possible with the grid graphics system
I simulated it adding a geom_point on the top of geom_segment; the hard part was to match the sizes which I guess it's easier having access to the graphic generation code.

node.title: Whiskers and outliers for geom_boxplot with transformed scale

node.body:
You're right, boxplots are calculated based on the transformed values, which affects the calculation of outliers. However, `StatBoxplot$compute_group()` has access to the x and y scales (and their transformations), so it is possible to change this.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/master/R/stat-boxplot.r#L82-L85

The only other place I can find a `Stat` that backtransforms a range is `stat_function()`: https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/master/R/stat-function.r#L93-L111

https://github.com/paleolimbot/ggplot2/blob/1f6f0cb4462aa9e3b5f51dc7fd594073e78351da/R/stat-function.r#L93-L111

It's worth noting that this (surprise at `Stat`s being calculated on transformed values) has been reported several times (#2880, #2804), and at least once it was deemed as a won't-fix: https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/issues/2804#issuecomment-410562015

Ah, sorry I missed those issues—I only searched for boxplot related ones.

Computing stats on the transformed values is potentially quite reasonable from a statistical perspective. If that's the way this goes, I would then just suggest a documentation update to note the behaviour since it's a bit surprising.

This topic came up at Lee Wilkinson's talk yesterday at SDSS 2019: Stats are computed on the transformed values. If you want the stats to be calculated on the original values then you need to work with a transformed coordinate system: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/coord_trans.html

This is common confusion in ggplot2: Many people try to use scales for things that should be done in coords. Setting axis limits without dropping data points is another common issue.

If that's true, it should be much easier to make a pretty looking plot with `coord_trans()` - right now the defaults don't produce the plot most people are looking for, `xlim` and `ylim` parameters aren't named the same as `coord_cartesian()`, non-default axis expansion isn't possible (#3338 and #2990), second axes aren't well-supported (#2990), and some of the nice things you can do like use `NA` as one of the limits aren't possible in coords (#2907). Even using `breaks = scales::log_breaks()` doesn't really work in `coord_trans()`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

p <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(cut, price)) +
  geom_boxplot() 

p + aes(y = log10(price))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/4QqK7He.png)

``` r
p + scale_y_log10()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/4pmJamT.png)

``` r
p + coord_trans(y = "log10")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/7WJy4Zl.png)

``` r
p + coord_trans(y = "log10") + scale_y_continuous(breaks = scales::log_breaks())
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/xvgN7qE.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-02 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

node.title: Alpha legend does not show full range alpha when transform is applied

node.body:
It looks like you have your `alpha_power_trans` coded incorrectly: the inverse should be `function(x) x^(1 / power))`, such that

``` r
alpha_power_trans <- function(power = 0.61) {
  scales::trans_new(
    "alpha_power", 
    trans = function(x) x^power,
    inverse = function(x) x^(1 / power)
  )
}

trans <- alpha_power_trans()
trans$inverse(trans$trans(10))
#> [1] 10
```

For your example:

``` r
library(ggplot2)

alpha_power_trans <- function(power = 0.61) {
  scales::trans_new(
    "alpha_power", 
    trans = function(x) x^power,
    inverse = function(x) x^(1 / power)
  )
}

p <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, alpha = Petal.Length)) +
  geom_point()

p
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/gWq4AYc.png)

``` r
p + scale_alpha(trans = alpha_power_trans(0.1))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/gdsxRiI.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>
I corrected the `alpha_power_trans` function and now it worked.

node.title: Remove extra space created by `coord_trans`

node.body:
you need to manually set you r discrete x expansions
``` r
library(ggplot2)
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggplot2':
#>   method         from 
#>   [.quosures     rlang
#>   c.quosures     rlang
#>   print.quosures rlang
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(patchwork)

## top panel
p1 <- ggplot(mpg, aes(class,cty) )+
  geom_quasirandom()+
  coord_trans(y="log2")+
  scale_x_discrete(expand=c(0,0.6))
## bottom panel
p2 <- ggplot(mpg, aes(class,fill=drv))+
     geom_bar(position = "fill")+
  scale_x_discrete(expand=c(0,0.6))

p1 + p2 + plot_layout(ncol = 1)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/JNj2tne.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
Thanks for the reply. But it doesn't fix the problem. If you see in `mpg` plot, last variable `suv` is not aligned to the above panel. I also tried adjusting `expand` values but not success yet.

It looks like `coord_trans()` doesn't expand its scales, nor is there an option to do so. The best way to do this would be to use `scale_y_continuous(trans = "log2")` rather than `coord_trans()`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(class, cty))+
  geom_boxplot() 

wrap_plots(
  p,
  p + scale_y_continuous(trans = "log2", breaks = seq(10, 35, by = 5)),
  ncol = 1
)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/nw2GC17.png)

If you really need `coord_trans()`, you can fudge it by setting `xlim` and `ylim` in `coord_cartesian()` (for the first plot) and `limx` and `limy` in `coord_trans()`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(class, cty))+
  geom_boxplot() 

wrap_plots(
  p + coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.4, 7.6), expand = FALSE),
  p + coord_trans(y = "log2", limx = c(0.4, 7.6)),
  ncol = 1
)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/Fu3Kr9i.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

Hi @paleolimbot thanks a lot for the suggestion. The second approach seems to be working as expected. 

When I used the first approach, after `scale_y_continuous` (replacing `coord_trans`) in my code above, the alternate shading effects were gone . But they were preserved with `coord_trans`. Do you see anything wrong in my code or is it something to do with `scale_y_continuous trans` args?

Thanks a lot for the help.

I don't think it's the `trans` arg, I think it's something to do with the way that you've coded `geom_rect()`. In particular, I think you're mapping some aesthetics when you need to set the aesthetics (outside `aes()`). This is how I would code what you're trying to do:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(class, cty)) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(class, cty)) +
  geom_rect(
    aes(xmin = xmin, xmax = xmax),
    data = data.frame(xmin = c(0.5, 3.5), xmax = c(1.5, 4.5)),
    ymax = Inf,
    ymin = -Inf,
    alpha = 0.1,
    inherit.aes = FALSE
  )

wrap_plots(
  p,
  p + scale_y_continuous(trans = "log2", breaks = seq(10, 35, by = 5)),
  ncol = 1
)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/8PX8j0K.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>
If I plot `geom_rect` after the points, point colors were faded slightly because of `rect` alpha. However, I will play around as per your suggestion. Thank you :)

I would encourage you to reach out at https://community.rstudio.com/ for questions like these! Here we are concerned with unexpected behaviour or features that you feel should be added. In this case, we're concerned with the irregular behaviour of scale expansion in `coord_trans()`.
Sure thing. Thanks for pointing it out.

node.title: position_dodge(2) default is "total"

node.body: I've [fixed the example](https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/pull/3340) in the documentation. The code examples you provided are working as intended, however. `preserve = "total"` has always been the default for `position_dodge()`, which is what you're using above, and we intentionally made it the default for `position_dodge2()` in #2386.
Fair dues, you're absolutely right. I was sure I'd used before and seen that behaviour.

node.title: draw_key_* should to be able to specify extra params

node.body: I don't understand what specifically you are requesting. Could you explain a specific use case/provide a mock-up?

sure. assume we have this:

```r
draw_key_foo <- function(data, params, size) {
    fooGrob(..., gp = gpar(fill = data$fill %||% 'gray20'))
}
```

and want to add a parameter that isn’t an aesthetic

```r
#' @importFrom gridSVG gradientFillGrob linearGradient
draw_key_foo <- function(data, params, size) {
    grob <- fooGrob(...)
    gradientFillGrob(grob, linearGradient(
        data$fill %||% 'gray20',
        params$fill2,
    ))
}
```

then I won’t be able to specify `geom_something(key_glyph ='foo', fill2 = ...)` because fill2 won’t be recognized as a valid parameter.

Could you use `Geom$extra_params`?

``` r
library(ggplot2)

draw_key_foo <- function(data, params, size) {
  message("Value of params$custom_param: ", format(params$custom_param))
  draw_key_point(data, params, size)
}

GeomPointFoo <- ggproto(
  "GeomPointFoo",
  GeomPoint,
  draw_key = draw_key_foo,
  extra_params = c(GeomPoint$extra_params, "custom_param")
)

geom_point_foo <- function(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity",
                           position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA,
                           inherit.aes = TRUE) {
  layer(
    data = data,
    mapping = mapping,
    stat = stat,
    geom = GeomPointFoo,
    position = position,
    show.legend = show.legend,
    inherit.aes = inherit.aes,
    params = list(
      na.rm = na.rm,
      ...
    )
  )
}

ggplot(mpg, aes(hwy, cty, col = class)) +
  geom_point_foo(custom_param = "Hi there!")
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
#> Value of params$custom_param: Hi there!
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/PDlWcyv.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

I think all of these suggestions are unidiomatic. The correct approach is to write a function factory that generates the specific key drawing function you need at that point in time. Just as we do, for example, with `scales::number_format()` to generate functions that format numbers.

When I wrote the `draw_key` patch I already had plans to write a function factory that can generate a broad range of key drawing functions that draw square keys. I just never got around to doing it, and I'm also not entirely sure whether it belongs into ggplot2 or into an extension package. If I have time over the next few days maybe I'll write an example implementation of what I have in mind.

@paleolimbot as I said initially: The fact that I have to write this wall of code is exactly my problem.

@clauswilke sure, that’ll work! Any idea what convention to use to name it? `key_renderer_foo`? `make_draw_key_foo`?

node.title: Option to center geom_step

node.body:
Just clarifying with a slightly simpler example - the default behaviour is this:

``` r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_step()
```

And you'd like to have something like the above code do this:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
df2 <- data.frame(x = 1:4, y = c(1:3, 3))
ggplot(df2, aes(x - 0.5, y)) + geom_step()
```

node.title: Place the extreme ticks at the edge of the legend frame without extra padding

node.body:
Set the `nbin` parameter to a large value (e.g., `nbin = 1000`). Maybe this should be added to the documentation.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(hp, disp, color = mpg)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_color_continuous(
    limits = c(10, 35),
    breaks = seq(10, 35, by = 5),
    guide = guide_colorbar(
      direction = "horizontal",
      title.position = "top", 
      title.hjust = 0.5, 
      ticks.colour = "white", 
      frame.colour = "black", 
      barwidth = 12,
      nbin = 1000
    )
  ) + 
  theme(legend.position = "top")
p
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/P4ZnPiY.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-05-31 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

This is exactly what I am looking for. Thank you very much. Before creating this issue, I have searched on the internet for several hours. I totally agree with you that some examples should be added to illustrate the function of `nbin` parameter in the documentation.

node.title: Layer data mapping are ignored in stat_function()

node.body:
Adding a reprex for clarity
``` r
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidyverse))
mtcars$vs <- as.factor(mtcars$vs)
mtcars %>%
  group_by(vs) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = mpg, fill = vs, colour = vs)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.1) +
  stat_function(aes(group = vs), fun = dnorm, args = list(mean = mean(mtcars$mpg), sd = sd(mtcars$mpg)))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/4Po1EmQ.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-13 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

`stat_function()` doesn't *actually* understand the group aesthetic...it is intended to display the result of one function over the x range. If there is more than one group, `stat_function()` will draw two copies of the result, but never actually looks at the data to get values. 

What you are trying to do is more like implementing your own `Stat`:

``` r
library(ggplot2)

StatNormalDensity <- ggproto(
  "StatNormalDensity", Stat,
  required_aes = "x",
  default_aes = aes(y = stat(y)),
  
  compute_group = function(data, scales, xlim = NULL, n = 101) {
    mean_value <- mean(data$x)
    sd_value <- sd(data$x)
    fun <- function(x) dnorm(x, mean = mean_value, sd = sd_value)
    StatFunction$compute_group(data, scales, fun = fun, xlim = xlim, n = n)
  }
)

mtcars$vs <- as.factor(mtcars$vs)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, fill = vs, colour = vs)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.1) +
  geom_line(stat = StatNormalDensity, size = 1)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/Vooa5VW.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-13 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

From the ggplot2 development perspective, It is assumed that all `Stat`s and `Geom`s understand the `group` aesthetic:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/R/stat-.r#L146-L148

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/R/geom-.r#L153-L155

Aesthetics will hopefully be better documented after #3293 is addressed, which should solve this issue.
Nice. We should probably clarify the docs then. (Maybe re-title this issue, and mark it for `tidy-dev-day`?)

I think it might also be worth modifying the constructor for `stat_function()` such that it warns if the user supplies either the `mapping` or `data`, since both are ignored anyway. Something like the warning in `geom_abline()` would work nicely:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/R/geom-abline.r#L88-L93

node.title: geom_ribbon expects an unused y-axis variable to be present

node.body:
This happens because you're inheriting the aesthetics from the main `ggplot()` call. If you don't want to inherit aesthetics, you need to explicitly say so with `inherit.aes = FALSE`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggplot2':
#>   method         from 
#>   [.quosures     rlang
#>   c.quosures     rlang
#>   print.quosures rlang

data <- data.frame(time = 1:10, value = 17 + runif(n = 10) * 4)
ribbon.data <- data.frame(time = data$time, ymin = data$value - 2, ymax = data$value + 2)

# doesn't work
ggplot(data, aes(x = time, y = value)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_ribbon(
    data = ribbon.data, aes(x = time, ymin = ymin, ymax = ymax), alpha = 0.2
  )
#> Error in FUN(X[[i]], ...): object 'value' not found

# works
ggplot(data, aes(x = time, y = value)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_ribbon(
    data = ribbon.data, aes(x = time, ymin = ymin, ymax = ymax), alpha = 0.2,
    inherit.aes = FALSE
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/KP69KWM.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-16 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

node.title: geom_sf : error when using comma as decimal separator

node.body: @thomasp85 and/or @clauswilke - is the support for unicode in ggplot2/grid robust enough to just use the degree symbol rather than resort to plotmath?
unicode support is a matter of the graphic device, not ggplot2/grid...
To answer your question better - most devices support unicode characters, but using plotmath ensures that the symbol font is used and by that, that the degree sign glyph is present in the font...

The expression text is generated here in sf:

https://github.com/r-spatial/sf/blob/master/R/graticule.R#L220-L235

Surrounding the degree text in quotes when created seems safest. @edzer - if the `degree_label`s in a `st_graticule()` look like `"0.4"*degree*W` instead of `0.4*degree*W`, would that cause problems elsewhere?

As far as I can tell, this particular problem arises because ggplot creates a plotmath expression, then converts it into a string, and then parses the string again. At that parsing stage, the number with a comma as separator is not understood. I don't remember now why I wrote the code this way, but there was a valid reason for it. I think it's because we build an internal data frame that holds x and y labels in the same column, and it is possible that only one of the two sets of labels uses plotmath.

One general solution may be to store everything as plotmath, rather than everything as strings. Turning numbers into strings may also work. Finally, if the R locale settings are changed so it understands a comma as a separator (I assume this is possible, I never use it) things should also work.

Relevant sections in the code:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/R/coord-sf.R#L80-L83

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/R/coord-sf.R#L116-L123

A workaround for now is to either set the labels manually or to provide functions that generate labels that R can parse later on.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(sf)
#> Linking to GEOS 3.6.1, GDAL 2.1.3, PROJ 4.9.3

nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"))
#> Reading layer `nc' from data source `/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.6/Resources/library/sf/shape/nc.shp' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
#> Simple feature collection with 100 features and 14 fields
#> geometry type:  MULTIPOLYGON
#> dimension:      XY
#> bbox:           xmin: -84.32385 ymin: 33.88199 xmax: -75.45698 ymax: 36.58965
#> epsg (SRID):    4267
#> proj4string:    +proj=longlat +datum=NAD27 +no_defs

degreeLabelsNS <- function(x) {
  pos = sign(x) + 2
  dir = c("*S", "", "*N")
  ggplot2:::parse_safe(paste0('"', abs(x), '"', "*degree", dir[pos]))
}

degreeLabelsEW <- function(x) {
  x <- ifelse(x > 180, x - 360, x)
  pos = sign(x) + 2
  if (any(x == -180))
    pos[x == -180] = 2
  if (any(x == 180))
    pos[x == 180] = 2
  dir = c("*W", "", "*E")
  ggplot2:::parse_safe(paste0('"', abs(x), '"', "*degree", dir[pos]))
}

options(OutDec = ",")

ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = nc) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    labels = degreeLabelsEW
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = degreeLabelsNS
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/haurq2W.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-17 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

It might make sense to add these helper functions to the scales package, which holds all sorts of similar functions, and to make them more configurable (number of decimal places shown, etc.). We can't change the source code of sf every time we want the labels to look a little different.

Just for completeness, here is the variation with a unicode degree symbol. If we provide these helper functions in scales, they could take an option to either generate plotmath or strings with unicode.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(sf)
#> Linking to GEOS 3.6.1, GDAL 2.1.3, PROJ 4.9.3

nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"))
#> Reading layer `nc' from data source `/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.6/Resources/library/sf/shape/nc.shp' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
#> Simple feature collection with 100 features and 14 fields
#> geometry type:  MULTIPOLYGON
#> dimension:      XY
#> bbox:           xmin: -84.32385 ymin: 33.88199 xmax: -75.45698 ymax: 36.58965
#> epsg (SRID):    4267
#> proj4string:    +proj=longlat +datum=NAD27 +no_defs

degreeLabelsNS <- function(x) {
  pos = sign(x) + 2
  dir = c("S", "", "N")
  paste0(abs(x), "°", dir[pos])
}

degreeLabelsEW <- function(x) {
  x <- ifelse(x > 180, x - 360, x)
  pos = sign(x) + 2
  if (any(x == -180))
    pos[x == -180] = 2
  if (any(x == 180))
    pos[x == 180] = 2
  dir = c("W", "", "E")
  paste0(abs(x), "°", dir[pos])
}

options(OutDec = ",")

ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = nc) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    labels = degreeLabelsEW
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = degreeLabelsNS
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/HDltJoN.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-17 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

The advantage of improving these functions in `sf` would be that they'd also work for base plots, we get less duplication. @paleolimbot I'm fine if there is no further fallout from this change (haven't tried).

@edzer My main point was that in the general case, we want to have these functions exported to the user and configurable. We may want to specify number of decimals, whether or not there's a space between the number and the degree symbol (as in `35 °N`), etc. See `dollar_format()` and `dollar()` as examples: https://rdrr.io/cran/scales/man/dollar_format.html It fits into scales, but of course you could also add similar functions to sf.

Regardless of the home for alternative graticule calculations, I think it's reasonable to have `coord_sf()` defaults work regardless of locale. I'll let @edzer have a look at the PR to sf to see if this this will cause problem elsewhere.

In ggplot2, it causes these expectations to fail:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b5606624cbd3cc5bb09fe2e008d1fada82daf44e/tests/testthat/test-coord_sf.R#L160-L173

I think it won't be hard to find another way to test this.
Thanks for this fast evaluation and workaround.

node.title: Rebuild the stable pkgdown site for 3.2.0

node.title: key_glyph behavior changes with different geoms

node.body:
Yes, it's confusing. The problem is that sometimes you want the `colour` color and sometimes you want the `fill` color, and sometimes you want both. What is needed is a set of glyph generators that allow you to specify what you want in a given scenario. (E.g.: provide me with a rectangular glyph that is filled with the color corresponding to the `colour` aesthetic.)

@paleolimbot Is this appropriate for the tidyverse dev day, or too complicated?
I would argue this is too much for dev day

Probably too much...off the top of my head I don't have a vision for what this looks like in code, so I imagine folks ad dev day won't either.

It seems trivial to me to make a custom glyph function for these (probably rare?) occasions. Documenting this could be a reasonable dev day activity, if this syntax is what you intended when writing the custom glyph bits:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
df2 = data.frame(x = rnorm(10), 
                 y = sample(letters[1:2], 10, TRUE))

draw_key_cust <- function(data, params, size) {
  data$fill <- data$colour
  draw_key_rect(data, params, size)
}

ggplot(df2, aes(y, x, color = y) ) +
  geom_boxplot(key_glyph = "cust")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/D29pxar.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-18 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

I like this idea for a custom glyph, and I think adding it to the docs is not a bad idea.

I was thinking about a much more complicated glyph factory that generates a glyph drawing function based on a number of parameter settings, but I have struggled with coming up with an appropriate API, so I've moved it to the backburner.

I went ahead and drew up an implementation for what I had in mind. Here it is.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(rlang)
library(grid)

rectangle_key_glyph <- function(colour = NA, fill = fill, alpha = alpha, size = size,
                                linetype = linetype, padding = unit(c(0, 0, 0, 0), "pt"),
                                color) {
  colour_aes <- enquo(colour)
  fill_aes <- enquo(fill)
  alpha_aes <- enquo(alpha)
  size_aes <- enquo(size)
  linetype_aes <- enquo(linetype)
  
  # enable US spelling
  color <- enquo(color)
  if (!quo_is_missing(color)) {
    colour_aes <- color
  }
  
  function(data, params, size) {
    if (is.null(data$size)) {
      data$size <- 0.5
    }
    
    # enable users to specify color with US spelling, "color"
    if (is.null(data$color)) {
      data$color <- data$colour
    }
  
    lwd <- min(eval_tidy(size_aes, data), min(size) / 4)
  
    rectGrob(
      x = unit(0.5, "npc") + 0.5*(padding[4] - padding[2]),
      y = unit(0.5, "npc") + 0.5*(padding[3] - padding[1]),
      width = unit(1, "npc") - unit(lwd, "mm") - padding[2] - padding[4],
      height = unit(1, "npc") - unit(lwd, "mm") - padding[1] - padding[3],
      gp = gpar(
        col = eval_tidy(colour_aes %||% NA, data),
        fill = scales::alpha(eval_tidy(fill_aes %||% "grey20", data), eval_tidy(alpha_aes, data)),
        lty = eval_tidy(linetype_aes %||% 1, data),
        lwd = lwd * .pt,
        linejoin = params$linejoin %||% "mitre",
        # `lineend` is a workaround for Windows and intentionally kept unexposed
        # as an argument. (c.f. https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/issues/3037#issuecomment-457504667)
        lineend = if (identical(params$linejoin, "round")) "round" else "square"
      )
    )
  }
}

df <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:5, each=3),
  y = 1:15,
  group = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each=5)
)

ggplot(df, aes(x, y, color = group)) +
  geom_line(
    key_glyph = rectangle_key_glyph(fill = color)
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/mDLHckL.png)

``` r

set.seed(1233)
df <- data.frame(
  x = rnorm(10), 
  y = sample(letters[1:2], 10, TRUE)
)

ggplot(df, aes(y, x, color = y)) +
  geom_boxplot(
    key_glyph = rectangle_key_glyph(fill = color, padding = margin(3, 3, 3, 3))
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/orxkgXe.png)

``` r

ggplot(df, aes(y, x, color = y)) +
  geom_boxplot(
    key_glyph = rectangle_key_glyph(
      fill = color, 
      color = "black", linetype = 3, size = 0.3,
      padding = margin(2, 2, 2, 2)
    )
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/onCxA6J.png)

``` r

ggplot(df, aes(y, x, color = y)) +
  geom_boxplot(
    key_glyph = rectangle_key_glyph(
      color = color, size = 1,
      padding = margin(1, 1, 1, 1)
    )
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/bVucMLi.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
@hadley Is the `rectangle_key_glyph()` function I drafted above something you'd want to see in ggplot2 proper, or would it be better placed in an extension package?
@clauswilke That feels a bit much for ggplot2 to me. It also provides similar features to `override.aes` which makes me ever so slightly worried.
Sounds good. I think I'll just stick it into cowplot.

This is now in the development version of cowplot, to be released as 1.0 soon.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(cowplot)
#> 
#> *******************************************************
#> Note: cowplot does not change the default ggplot2 theme
#> anymore. To recover the previous behavior, execute:
#>   theme_set(theme_cowplot())
#> *******************************************************

ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(
    key_glyph = rectangle_key_glyph(fill = color, padding = margin(2, 2, 2, 2))
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/wmgTXrR.png)

``` r

economics_long %>%
  filter(variable != "pop") %>%
  ggplot(aes(date, value, color = variable)) +
  geom_line(
    key_glyph = circle_key_glyph(
      fill = color, color = "black", size = .2, padding = margin(2, 2, 2, 2)
    )
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/rnsreoU.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I can't think of a good example that could be added to the `draw_key` documentation that can't be solved by `override.aes` or by the new code that is now in cowplot.

node.title: Single strategy for scale expansion/limiting that works with transformations

node.body: In a slightly similar way, coordinate systems should probably be able to replace scale defaults that aren't explicitly set (should they?). Off the top of my head, `coord_trans()` should probably be able to coerce the (unset) breaks and labels on the transformed axes to `trans$breaks` or `trans$labels`, and there is one open issue on something similar with `coord_fixed()` (#2888)

node.title: How to create a manual legend (using geom_blank()?)

node.body:
The documentation advertises that `geom_blank()` is a good way to ensure common scales between plots, which appears to work:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
blank <- geom_blank(aes(color = Species), data = iris)
ggplot(iris[iris$Species == "setosa", ]) +
  geom_blank(aes(color = Species), data = iris) +
  geom_point(aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Petal.Length, color = Species))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/exRAmTj.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-21 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

Is there a common use case where one might want to draw a blank plot with a legend?

I attempted to use geom_blank() to create a legend for layers in which the color/fill is manually supplied (not by aesthetic mapping). 

I thought this would be clever since my initial idea did not pan out.  And of course the same behavior occurs when `geom = "blank"` is called.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
#> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 3.5.3
ggplot(iris) +
    geom_point(aes(NA, NA, color = Species))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/k93BR18.png)

``` r

ggplot(iris) +
    stat_identity(aes(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length, color = Species), geom = "blank", show.legend = TRUE)
#> Warning: Ignoring unknown aesthetics: x, y, colour
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/2Q717Yl.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-21 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

That's a good point...I don't know how to do that, and you're not the first person who has asked. I've retitled the issue to focus future discussion: if geom_blank() does not map color for discrete variable and does not show legend for continuous variable, then how does one create a manual legend? It seems like this should be possible.

I don't understand the problem. Can somebody provide a reprex that would require a manual legend? I feel quite certain that appropriate solutions exist for pretty much any legend scenario that one might want to achieve.
I've never had a use for it, but @gvwilson asked if it were possible during my tidyverse exam.

Here are two examples of what I imagine "manual legend" could mean. Does either cover the desired use case? I'm not sure how a legend could be more manual.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# manual mapping across multiple layers
ggplot(mapping = aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width)) +
  geom_point(data = filter(iris, Species == "setosa"), aes(color = "setosa")) +
  geom_point(data = filter(iris, Species == "virginica"), aes(color = "virginica")) +
  geom_point(data = filter(iris, Species == "versicolor"), aes(color = "versicolor")) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(setosa = "red", virginica = "blue", versicolor = "green")
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/bXJ5TEl.png)

``` r
  
# mapping color values from data frame directly
iris %>% mutate(
  color = case_when(
    Species == "setosa" ~ "red",
    Species == "virginica" ~ "blue",
    Species == "versicolor" ~ "green"
  )
) %>%
  ggplot(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = color)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_identity(
    guide = guide_legend(),
    breaks = c("red", "green", "blue"),
    labels = c("setosa", "versicolor", "virginica")
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/fp6OHBi.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I am also unsure how it could be more manual, other than adding a guide that draws an arbitrary grob. Either way, I don't think that `geom_blank()` was ever intended to do this, so I am closing.

node.title: Does the "ggplot2 internal programming guidelines" vignette referenced in data.frame() error messages exist?

node.body: You're right that there is no "internal programming guidelines" vignette! However this isn't a change that will break any code in other packages, because `data.frame` is not exported from ggplot2.

I'm getting reports of this error from users of ggformula when the update ggplot2.  So I think it depends on how the packages uses ggplot2.  See for example

* https://github.com/ProjectMOSAIC/ggformula/issues/127

The problem is that ggformula keeps copies of ggplot2 functions because of the way that `ggformula::layer_factory()` works. Therefore, the built version of the package contains copies of whatever ggplot2 version CRAN had when the package was built. If this is your package, please fix this! A short-term workaround is to `install.packages(..., type = "source")`.

node.title: could we have support for crayon in titles and labels ?

node.body:
Colored text is currently in the works (see example below). However, it's not based on crayon, it's based on markdown/html. We could support crayon if somebody wrote a function that can convert crayon output to html. This is maybe a task for the crayon developers? I'm closing this issue because it is covered by #3373. ``` r library(ggplot2) library(gridtext) ```
ggplot2 helper code ``` r library(grid) library(rlang) # define new theme element that inherits from `element_text()` element_markdown <- function(family = NULL, face = NULL, colour = NULL, size = NULL, hjust = NULL, vjust = NULL, angle = NULL, lineheight = NULL, color = NULL, margin = NULL, debug = FALSE, inherit.blank = FALSE) { if (!is.null(color)) colour <- color structure( list( family = family, face = face, colour = colour, size = size, hjust = hjust, vjust = vjust, angle = angle, lineheight = lineheight, margin = margin, debug = debug, inherit.blank = inherit.blank), class = c("element_markdown", "element_text", "element") ) } # rendering of the theme element is handled by `labels_grob()` element_grob.element_markdown <- function(element, label = "", x = NULL, y = NULL, family = NULL, face = NULL, colour = NULL, size = NULL, hjust = NULL, vjust = NULL, angle = NULL, lineheight = NULL, margin = NULL, margin_x = FALSE, margin_y = FALSE, ...) { if (is.null(label)) return(ggplot2:::zeroGrob()) vj <- vjust %||% element$vjust hj <- hjust %||% element$hjust margin <- margin %||% element$margin %||% ggplot2::margin(0, 0, 0, 0) angle <- angle %||% element$angle %||% 0 x <- x %||% hj if (!is.unit(x)) x <- unit(x, "npc") y <- y %||% vj if (!is.unit(y)) y <- unit(y, "npc") markdown_grob(label, x = x, y = y, hjust = hj, vjust = vj, angle = angle, padding = margin, debug = element$debug) } ```
``` r ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) + geom_point(show.legend=TRUE, alpha = 0.5) + scale_color_manual( values = c("#0072B2", "#E69F00", "#009E73"), guide = "none" ) + labs( title = "Sepal **lengths** and **widths** of *Iris* species", subtitle = "I. setosa | I. versicolor | I. virginica", x = "Sepal **length** (cm)", y = "Sepal **width** (cm)" ) + theme_minimal() + theme( plot.title = element_markdown(margin = ggplot2::margin(5, 0, 5, 0)), plot.subtitle = element_markdown(), axis.title.x = element_markdown(), axis.title.y = element_markdown(vjust = 0.5, hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 5.5)) ) ``` ![](https://i.imgur.com/Ls1NpnB.png) Created on 2019-06-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)
This is awesome @clauswilke, thanks for the great work

@clauswilke could it be that @gaborcsardi 's `ansistrings::ansi_to_html` is what you're alluding to ? It didn't catch the italic but colors seem to work fine! (note: reprex didn't display the colors strangely so i had to upload separately).

``` r
glue_html <- function(txt, ...){
  txt <- withr::with_package("crayon", glue::glue(txt, ...))
  ansistrings::ansi_to_html(text = txt, fullpage = FALSE)
}
glue_col_html <-  function(txt, ...){
  txt <- withr::with_package("crayon", glue::glue_col(txt, ...))
  ansistrings::ansi_to_html(text = txt, fullpage = FALSE)
}

ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(show.legend=TRUE, alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("#0072B2", "#E69F00", "#009E73"),
    guide = "none"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = glue_col_html("Sepal {blue lengths} and {green widths} of {red Iris} species"),
    subtitle = glue_html("{blue$italic('I. setosa')} | {yellow$italic('I. setosa')} | {cyan$italic('I. setosa')}"),
    x = "Sepal **length** (cm)", y = "Sepal **width** (cm)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_markdown(margin = ggplot2::margin(5, 0, 5, 0)),
    plot.subtitle = element_markdown(),
    axis.title.x = element_markdown(),
    axis.title.y = element_markdown(vjust = 0.5, hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 5.5))
  )
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/9mkadxK.png)

Yes, this function does what I would need. The reason why the italics isn't picked up is because `ansi_to_html()` uses CSS to set the italics font style, and that isn't yet implemented in gridtext (it currently expects the `` or `` tags). However, it's possible to mix crayon and markdown (see below), so this is not that big of an issue. And in any case, support for `font-style:italic` is easy to add. ```r glue_html <- function(txt, ...){ txt <- withr::with_package("crayon", glue::glue(txt, ...)) ansistrings::ansi_to_html(text = txt, fullpage = FALSE) } glue_html("{blue$italic('I. setosa')}") #> I. setosa ``` Could you file an issue for the [gridtext package](https://github.com/clauswilke/gridtext/issues)? The right way to do this would be to add an `element_crayon()` (see below). One problem, though, is that crayon auto-detects whether colors are available, and it apparently doesn't work inside of R Markdown. I had to copy and paste the image manually in the example below. ``` r library(ggplot2) library(gridtext) library(grid) library(rlang) library(crayon) # define new theme element that inherits from `element_text()` element_crayon <- function(family = NULL, face = NULL, colour = NULL, size = NULL, hjust = NULL, vjust = NULL, angle = NULL, lineheight = NULL, color = NULL, margin = NULL, debug = FALSE, inherit.blank = FALSE) { if (!is.null(color)) colour <- color structure( list( family = family, face = face, colour = colour, size = size, hjust = hjust, vjust = vjust, angle = angle, lineheight = lineheight, margin = margin, debug = debug, inherit.blank = inherit.blank), class = c("element_crayon", "element_text", "element") ) } element_grob.element_crayon <- function(element, label = "", x = NULL, y = NULL, family = NULL, face = NULL, colour = NULL, size = NULL, hjust = NULL, vjust = NULL, angle = NULL, lineheight = NULL, margin = NULL, margin_x = FALSE, margin_y = FALSE, ...) { if (is.null(label)) return(ggplot2:::zeroGrob()) vj <- vjust %||% element$vjust hj <- hjust %||% element$hjust margin <- margin %||% element$margin %||% ggplot2::margin(0, 0, 0, 0) angle <- angle %||% element$angle %||% 0 x <- x %||% hj if (!is.unit(x)) x <- unit(x, "npc") y <- y %||% vj if (!is.unit(y)) y <- unit(y, "npc") markdown_grob(ansistrings::ansi_to_html(text = label, fullpage = FALSE), x = x, y = y, hjust = hj, vjust = vj, angle = angle, padding = margin, debug = element$debug) } ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) + geom_point(show.legend=TRUE, alpha = 0.5) + scale_color_manual( values = c("#0072B2", "#E69F00", "#009E73"), guide = "none" ) + labs( title = paste("Sepal", blue("lengths"), "and", green("widths"), "of *Iris* species"), subtitle = paste(blue('*I. setosa*'), "|", yellow('*I. setosa*'), "|", cyan('*I. setosa*')), x = "Sepal length (cm)", y = "Sepal width (cm)" ) + theme_minimal() + theme( plot.title = element_crayon(margin = ggplot2::margin(5, 0, 5, 0)), plot.subtitle = element_crayon() ) ```

node.title: ggplot2 plots out of order

node.body: Could you please post a reproducible example that illustrates your problem?

Part of this is what was implemented in scales:
https://scales.r-lib.org/reference/index.html
https://www.tidyverse.org/articles/2018/08/scales-1-0-0/

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
set.seed(5678)

df <- tibble(a = runif(100, min = 0, max = 1),
       b = rnorm(100))

df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = a, y = b)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/VulB9ap.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-06-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

The solution to my problem was to use order my percentage columns, use rBase and output as different dataframe, then define my factors and levels, and then change the percentage to columns. Now ggplot will plot an axis from 1-100 without issue.

The feature I would like added to ggplot is an order variable. Something like order = "numeric", "alphabetic", "yValue", and the a secondary component that allows me to stipulate ascending or descending. This would make my life a lot easier for all graphics I produce in ggplot - not just this one example. 

I understand there are lots of work-arounds. However, I do strongly believe for such an advanced and widely used package such features should be incorporated into the base source code.

Isn't it \n

node.title: rlang_exec not found

node.body: I cannot reproduce this. I think something is wrong with your rlang installation. Could you try re-installing rlang? (`rlang_exec` is C implementation inside `exec()`)

I know it is something specific, I cannot reproduce it on another system either.
I will try to re-install `rlang` one more time.
I think it has something to do with the upgrade of `rlang` from pre `0.4.x` version to `0.4.x`.
Can it be caused by the fact I pulled all the packages from github rather than cran?

Found the issue.
For some reason, while installing from github (`devtools::install_github("r-lib/rlang", force = TRUE)`), I missed this one line of the output:
```
Warning in file.copy(files, dest, overwrite = TRUE) :
  problem copying .\rlang.dll to *my_path*\rlang.dll: Permission denied
```
Surprisingly, failure to copy the dll does not result in the installation error.
`ggplot` just happened to be the first package I used right after I finished the installation, hence the error.

I guess `rlang` is used at some point by `devtools`/`remotes` while installing, and therefore the library is in use.
I did a clean install from cran using `install.package` and everything works fine.

You can use `remotes::install_github()` on a fresh session. (c.f. https://yutani.rbind.io/post/a-survival-guide-to-install-rlang-from-github-on-windows/). Anyway I'm closing this as this doesn't seem a ggplot2's issue in any case. Thanks for confirming!

node.title: geom_area with negative y not working in ggplot2 3.2.0

node.body:
A simpler version of code (Sorry, I can't render the reprex right now...). Not sure what's happening here, but it seems something went wrong...

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(
  x = 1:6,
  y = c(1, 2, 2, 1, 0, -1)
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_area(fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(d, aes(x, y - 1)) +
  geom_area(fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point()
```

Rendered reprex below.

@thomasp85 Is this somehow related to the rewritten polygon rendering code? We may have to consider a hotfix release, since this is a serious regression.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(
  x = 1:6,
  y = c(1, 2, 2, 1, 0, -1)
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_area(fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/pXtEiIJ.png)

``` r

ggplot(d, aes(x, y - 1)) +
  geom_area(fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/MTLvYIb.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-03 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I’ll look into it.

This is due to `GeomArea`/`GeomRibbon` now sorting their data in `setup_data` instead of in `draw_panel`. `PositionStack` changes the ordering of the data and that is no longer resolved as it comes after `setup_data`.

There are two ways around this. 

1) Make sure PositionStack doesn't change the ordering of data
2) Make a secondary sort in `draw_panel()`

I generally prefer 1) as it is how I think positions should behave (i.e. not fiddle with data ordering), but it may have unforeseen consequences 🤷‍♂️

I agree this should be fixed in a hot fix (and we really should have some tests to catch this) cc @hadley
1) sounds reasonable. And it shouldn't be too bad to do a patch release for this issue. Do we want to wait a week in case any other problems come in?
Let's wait a week before we start release process

If I recall correctly, the ordering in PositionStack exists to fix my first ever bug report (#1552) 🙂. So it is there for a reason, but it's possible that reason has been obviated by other changes since. I can try to look into it this weekend.

I've opened a PR that will address this, but in the meantime `geom_ribbon()` still works:

``` r
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(115)

ggplot(
  data.frame(
    x = 1:100,
    y = cumsum(rnorm(n = 100, mean = 0, sd = 3))
  ),
  aes(x, y)) +
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymax = y, ymin = 0), fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_path()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/t8N1HAb.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-17 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

@thomasp85 @hadley 
> Let's wait a week before we start release process

Some weeks have passed. Do we start the process? While this issue should be hot-fixed, this might not be as serious as we thought at first in terms of the number of users affected, considering the fact there's no other issues filed than this one. So, if you are very busy (sorry, I don't think I can review #3401...), I think it's okay not to hurry so much.

But, I'm a bit worrying about that the CRAN check is all red probably due to #3394 (, which seems already fixed by @paleolimbot). Do you get any serious warnings about this from CRAN people?

https://cran.rstudio.com/web/checks/check_results_ggplot2.html
I’m currently on vacation (this week and next).  I’ll begin release once I’m back
OK. Have a nice vacation!

node.title: geom_sf() "missing aesthetics: geometry" with tibble but not data frame

node.body:
The conversion to tibble strips the special geospatial information that `st_as_sf()` had added, and ggplot2 uses that information to automatically find the geometry column.

If you need to work with tibbles like that, you can always map the geometry column manually.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(tibble)
library(sf)
#> Linking to GEOS 3.6.1, GDAL 2.1.3, PROJ 4.9.3
library(maps)
us <- st_as_sf(map("state", plot = FALSE, fill = TRUE))
us_tbl <- as_tibble(us)

class(us)
#> [1] "sf"         "data.frame"
us
#> Simple feature collection with 49 features and 1 field
#> geometry type:  MULTIPOLYGON
#> dimension:      XY
#> bbox:           xmin: -124.6813 ymin: 25.12993 xmax: -67.00742 ymax: 49.38323
#> epsg (SRID):    4326
#> proj4string:    +proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs
#> First 10 features:
#>                          geometry                   ID
#> 1  MULTIPOLYGON (((-87.46201 3...              alabama
#> 2  MULTIPOLYGON (((-114.6374 3...              arizona
#> 3  MULTIPOLYGON (((-94.05103 3...             arkansas
#> 4  MULTIPOLYGON (((-120.006 42...           california
#> 5  MULTIPOLYGON (((-102.0552 4...             colorado
#> 6  MULTIPOLYGON (((-73.49902 4...          connecticut
#> 7  MULTIPOLYGON (((-75.80231 3...             delaware
#> 8  MULTIPOLYGON (((-77.13731 3... district of columbia
#> 9  MULTIPOLYGON (((-85.01548 3...              florida
#> 10 MULTIPOLYGON (((-80.89018 3...              georgia

class(us_tbl)
#> [1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"
us_tbl
#> # A tibble: 49 x 2
#>                                                     geometry ID            
#>                                           <MULTIPOLYGON [°]> <chr>         
#>  1 (((-87.46201 30.38968, -87.48493 30.37249, -87.52503 30.… alabama       
#>  2 (((-114.6374 35.01918, -114.6431 35.10512, -114.603 35.1… arizona       
#>  3 (((-94.05103 33.03675, -94.05103 33.30031, -94.05676 33.… arkansas      
#>  4 (((-120.006 42.00927, -120.006 41.20139, -120.006 39.700… california    
#>  5 (((-102.0552 40.00964, -102.061 40.00391, -102.0552 39.5… colorado      
#>  6 (((-73.49902 42.04937, -73.04066 42.04364, -73.01201 42.… connecticut   
#>  7 (((-75.80231 39.72889, -75.76221 39.72889, -75.74503 39.… delaware      
#>  8 (((-77.13731 38.94394, -77.06283 38.99551, -77.01699 38.… district of c…
#>  9 (((-85.01548 30.99702, -84.99829 30.96264, -84.97537 30.… florida       
#> 10 (((-80.89018 32.0398, -80.85007 32.02834, -80.84435 32.0… georgia       
#> # … with 39 more rows

ggplot(data = us_tbl, aes(geometry = geometry)) + geom_sf()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/QM8FgXy.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-03 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Note: this may have changed from 3.1.0, because we have rewritten the code that finds geometry columns. I would argue, though, that if the data given to ggplot2 is not of type `sf` then ggplot2 should not try to auto-map the geometry column. One could ask whether `as_tibble()` should retain the `sf` class attribute, but that's a question for the tibble maintainers.
I wonder if the error message can contain some useful hints about what to do next (maybe a handy issue for tidy dev day?).

Ah, thank you! In my existing code I wasn't converting to a tibble explicitly, but I was joining a tibble with a data frame produced by st_read(), which I guess converted the result to a tibble. I modified my existing code to add an explicit "aes(..., geometry = geometry)" and that fixed the problem.

My apologies for filing an issue over this. I did a fair amount of Internet searching to try to track down what could be causing the error, but couldn't find any useful information. And since my code was working under the previous version of ggplot2 I presumed that this was a bug introduced in the current version.
@frankhecker I think it's a reasonable issue. The behavior is unexpected and confusing. It's just not obvious to me that ggplot2 is the right place to fix this.

I dug a little deeper and I think the overall behavior is correct and doesn't require any changes. The join functions seem to maintain the class of their first argument, so if you need to join something into an `sf` data frame you just have to make sure that that data frame is the first argument. Depending on your application, you may need to use `right_join()` instead of `left_join()`. And `as_tibble()` converts whatever you give it into a tibble, so that's appropriate as well.

``` r
library(tidyverse)

# get first four lines of nc file
nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)[1:4, ] %>%
  mutate(NAME = as.character(NAME))

d <- tibble(
  NAME = c("Ashe", "Alleghany", "Surry", "Currituck"),
  value = rnorm(4)
)

# result is sf
nc2 <- left_join(nc, d)
#> Joining, by = "NAME"
class(nc2)
#> [1] "sf"         "data.frame"
ggplot(nc2) + geom_sf()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/LaDHUuw.png)

``` r

# result is tibble
nc3 <- left_join(d, nc)
#> Joining, by = "NAME"
class(nc3)
#> [1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"
# doesn't work
ggplot(nc3) + geom_sf()
#> Error: stat_sf requires the following missing aesthetics: geometry
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/sQazw1V.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-04 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I agree with your conclusions. Your point about join order is well-taken, I'll keep it in mind. Thanks for your attention to this issue, and thanks to all of you working on ggplot2!

node.title: update_geom_defaults doesn't modify label.size or label.padding

node.body:
`update_geom_default()` only works on aesthetics, and `label.size` and `label.padding` are currently implemented as parameters. A workaround is to redefine `geom_label()`:

``` r
library(tidyverse)
#> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'rvest':
#>   method            from
#>   read_xml.response xml2
ggplot2::update_geom_defaults("label", list(size = 18 / .pt,
                                            fill = "white",
                                            colour = "orange",
                                            lineheight = 0.75))

geom_label <- function(..., label.size = NA, label.padding = unit(.1, "lines")) {
  ggplot2::geom_label(..., label.size = label.size, label.padding = label.padding)
}

mtcars %>%
  rownames_to_column("car") %>% 
  mutate(car = str_replace_all(car, " ", "\n")) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg, label = car)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_label() 
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/niHNdY8.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-05 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>
Thanks very much @paleolimbot, that’s really useful.

node.title: NULL as default for xlab() and ylab()

node.body: I created PR #3395 if you think that this change is useful.

While I feel your suggestion is smart, I'm a bit afraid this might make the semantics of `labs()` a bit confusing. For example, if this would remove axis labels,

``` r
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) + geom_col() + xlab() + ylab()
```

one might think this would remove all labels,

``` r
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) + geom_col() + labs()
```

but actually `labs()` does nothing. So, I'd rather stick with the status quo, where we need to specify `NULL` explicitly to remove labels.
Good point, forgot about `labs()`! Will close this then 👍

node.title: predictive-practice-with-R
Plot annotation text only once and outside plot region

node.body: Use a secondary x axis?

A secondary axis won't work until #3171 is implemented, since second axes don't currently work with discrete scales. The best that can be done now is using `geom_text()` and `coord_cartesian(clip = "off")`:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

mpg_labs <- mpg %>%
  count(class) %>%
  mutate(
    label = paste0("n = ", n),
    drv = 4
  )

ggplot(mpg, aes(class, hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_text(aes(class, y = Inf, label = label), data = mpg_labs, vjust = -0.5) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(drv)) +
  coord_cartesian(clip = "off") +
  theme(plot.margin = margin(20, 2, 2, 2, unit = "pt"))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/RMrRlTr.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-07 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.1)</sup>

I find out what I ignored in your code @paleolimbot, add `params$class = "Signature_1"` fix my problem.

 Thanks for your help.

Also thanks to @clauswilke, your idea is clear and simple. I hope it will be implemented soon.

node.title: ggplot2 legends making no sense.

node.body:
Thanks for providing a detailed reprex. In looking over the code, I don't see anywhere where ggplot2 does anything unexpected. It looks to me like you're not sufficiently familiar with how aesthetic mappings and scales work, and therefore you are surprised when ggplot2 does exactly what you ask it to do.

I recommend that you read some introductory texts about ggplot2. For example, Kieran Healy's book (http://socviz.co/) is great. It discusses your specific problem in Chapter 3.5: http://socviz.co/makeplot.html#mapping-aesthetics-vs-setting-them

If you have further questions about ggplot2 usage, the R Studio forums would be a more appropriate venue.

In any case, this is out of ggplot2's control. If seeting `useDingbats = FALSE` in `ggsave()` doesn't resolve the issue then it's a problem with the underlying pdf device.

node.title: Cloning doesn't exactly clone

node.body:
If this is a feature that multiple extension packages use, then maybe we should consider adding a  clone function to `layer`. In this way, the packages should continue to work even if the underlying layer implementation changes. I'm a bit worried about extension packages doing all sorts of hacks assuming specific implementation details of ggplot2, it really limits our ability to make changes to the code base.

Maybe @hadley knows whether the `clone_layer()` function above is correct and reliable.
For what it's worth, internally we use `ggproto(NULL, self)` to achieve a similar result.
Duh, yes, to make a copy of a ggproto object you instantiate a new one that derives from the old one.

> For what it's worth, internally we use `ggproto(NULL, self)` to achieve a similar result.

Oh, that's beautiful, absolutely obvious and it works! :tada: 
Thanks a lot!

> I'm a bit worried about extension packages doing all sorts of hacks assuming specific implementation details of ggplot2, it really limits our ability to make changes to the code base.

I think the responsibility should lay solely on extension authors if they (us) are bending the internals of the plots.

> I think the responsibility should lay solely on extension authors if they (us) are bending the internals of the plots.

My point is that extension authors can engage with the ggplot2 developers to make sure the ggplot2 API supports the required features. That's almost always better than just working around limitations in ggplot2 with ugly hacks.

Fair point. In my case, it was an organic process that started by just playing around trying to understand the ggplot2 internals and almost accidentally creating something usable. 

Do you have any suggestions on how to integrate ggnewscale better with ggplot2 to make it more robust and less hacky?

I'm not sure I have any specific suggestions for ggnewscale. You're tackling a complicated problem and it's not clear what the best approach is. In general, I would say that if you think "I wish the ggplot2 API could do X", it's not a bad idea to open an issue and ask. It may not be possible to add X, but it may also be the case that simply nobody has thought about it yet, or that there's another way to achieve the goal you have. In other words, what you did here in this issue is exactly the right approach.

node.title: Setting hjust in geom_text cannot align labels with different length

node.body: Yes, this is how `hjust` works. It's not meant for general purpose positioning, only for aligning. You'll have to find another way of moving the labels up. For example, you could append a space to the beginning of each string.
Thanks :)

node.title: draw_key_dotplot : more detailed documentation please (ggplot2 v3.2.0)

node.body:
They are not intended to be called directly by you, but inside ggplot2. You just can pass the function as it is (or define one by yourself like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/57205560/5397672)):

``` r
ggplot() +
  geom_jitter(data = points, aes(x = bc, y = bpc, fill = cluster), shape = 21, size = 1, 
              key_glyph = draw_key_dotplot)
```

I agree this might be a bit confusing. We may need to consider raising an error when `draw_key_*()` is called on the global env...?

And, here's the result what you want; you can tweak the legends via `guides()`.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

points <- data.frame(bc = c (1:3), bpc = c(1:3), cluster = c("red", "green", "blue"))

ggplot() +
  geom_jitter(data = points, aes(x = bc, y = bpc, fill = cluster), shape = 21, size = 1) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(override.aes = list(size = 5)))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/LZLkYj8.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-28 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
thank you @yutannihilation

node.title: Time not showing in scale_*_datetime()

node.body:
The breaks are made at nice round numbers; in this case, they are `2018/11/12 00:00:00`, `2018/11/05 00:00:00` and `2018/10/29 00:00:00`, so the format `"%H:%M:%S"` gives `00:00:00`.

If you want labels at the exact places of the points, you need to specify `breaks` by yourself:

``` r
ggplot(tt, aes(x = data, y = value, colour = variable)) +
  scale_y_datetime(breaks = tt$value, date_labels = "%H:%M:%S") +
  geom_point()
```

node.title: Discrete scales cannot handle continuous values

node.body: It seems the change was introduced by #3426.

`self$range$range` can be `NULL` because `train()` is bypassed when `is.discrete()` returns `FALSE`.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/141c77537ea4f54a7949ed8f23fd02c50172960e/R/scale-discrete-.r#L77-L83

So, to fix this minimally, we can change the line 91 to `self$range$range %||% integer()`:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/141c77537ea4f54a7949ed8f23fd02c50172960e/R/scale-discrete-.r#L85-L97

node.title: Indexing data.tables and groups defined by strings

node.body:
Could you please turn this into a self-contained [reprex](http://reprex.tidyverse.org/) (short for minimal **repr**oducible **ex**ample)? It will help us help you if we can be sure we're all working with/looking at the same stuff.

If you've never heard of a reprex before, you might want to start by reading the tidyverse.org [help page](https://www.tidyverse.org/help/).

You can install reprex by running (you may already have it, though, if you have the tidyverse package installed):
```r
install.packages("reprex")
```

Thanks

Thanks. I wasn't able to get reprex() to work properly in my environment, but I think the code/output below should be clear.

Below is a reprex for the issue of ggplot creating a persistent index (and apologies if that is not the correct terminology - economist, not programmer).

(I haven't been able to create a simple reprex of the problem of not all categories of a variable being graphed; some of the extra complexity in the data.table below comes from my efforts to do so.)

```
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)

ex_dt <- data.table(var1 = c("high", "high", "low", "low", "high", "high", "low", "low"),
                    var2 = c("x", "y", "x", "y", "x", "y", "x", "y"),
                    year = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2),
                    value = c(1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 3, 2, 2))
str(ex_dt)

## Classes 'data.table' and 'data.frame':   8 obs. of  4 variables:
##  $ var1 : chr  "high" "high" "low" "low" ...
##  $ var2 : chr  "x" "y" "x" "y" ...
##  $ year : num  1 1 1 1 2 2 2 2
##  $ value: num  1 1 2 1 2 3 2 2
##  - attr(*, ".internal.selfref")=<externalptr>

ggplot()+
  geom_area(data = ex_dt[var1 == "low" & var2 %in% c("x", "y")], 
            aes(x = year, y = value, fill = var2))
```
GRAPH OMITTED - NOT INTERESTING

```
str(ex_dt)

## Classes 'data.table' and 'data.frame':   8 obs. of  4 variables:
##  $ var1 : chr  "high" "high" "low" "low" ...
##  $ var2 : chr  "x" "y" "x" "y" ...
##  $ year : num  1 1 1 1 2 2 2 2
##  $ value: num  1 1 2 1 2 3 2 2
##  - attr(*, ".internal.selfref")=<externalptr> 
##  - attr(*, "index")= int 
##   ..- attr(*, "__var2__var1")= int  1 5 3 7 2 6 4 8
```

I'm not able to reproduce this when I do _not_ subset the data inside the ggplot call. It seems to be a product of the subsetting (see last example where I subset the data outside of ggplot2. 

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)

ex_dt <- data.table(var1 = c("high", "high", "low", "low", "high", "high", "low", "low"),
                    var2 = c("x", "y", "x", "y", "x", "y", "x", "y"),
                    year = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2),
                    value = c(1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 3, 2, 2))
str(ex_dt)
#> Classes 'data.table' and 'data.frame':   8 obs. of  4 variables:
#>  $ var1 : chr  "high" "high" "low" "low" ...
#>  $ var2 : chr  "x" "y" "x" "y" ...
#>  $ year : num  1 1 1 1 2 2 2 2
#>  $ value: num  1 1 2 1 2 3 2 2
#>  - attr(*, ".internal.selfref")=<externalptr>


ggplot(data = ex_dt, aes(x = var2, y = value)) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/VdECI9S.png)

``` r

str(ex_dt)
#> Classes 'data.table' and 'data.frame':   8 obs. of  4 variables:
```

node.title: `facet_wrap` and `facet_grid` throwing `scale_apply` related errors

node.body:
I couldn't reproduce the error (w/ R 3.6.1 and the dev version of ggplot2, tibble and vctrs). Is this specific to R 3.5...?

``` r
library(ggplot2)

p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) + geom_point()
p + facet_wrap(vars(class))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/X4jQlnI.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-07-31 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
Thanks. Had the dev versions of ggplot2 and tibble, but not vctrs. Upgrading to the dev version of vctrs did the trick. Now works on 3.5...

Oh, really? But your session info says...

``` r
#>  Github (r-lib/vctrs@6528543)      
```

Anyway, glad that it works fine now! (It seems tibble and vctrs are under heavy development, so it might be good to stay with the CRAN versions of them for now)

node.title: qplot() ylab behavior changed, now defaults to NULL

node.body:
Thanks, confirmed. As you say, it seems this used to work before #2936, sorry...

``` r
packageVersion("ggplot2")
#> [1] '3.1.1'

library(ggplot2)
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggplot2':
#>   method         from 
#>   [.quosures     rlang
#>   c.quosures     rlang
#>   print.quosures rlang

set.seed(2009)
x <- rnorm(100)
qplot(x, geom="histogram")
#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/fU4LTji.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-05 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
Now I feel both are wrong; shouldn't the label be `count`, the same as `ggplot() + geom_histogram()`...?

I agree. 

`qplot(x, geom="histogram")` should be the same as 
`ggplot(aes(x=x), data=data.frame(x=x))+geom_histogrram()`

`qplot(x, geom="density")` should be the same as `ggplot(aes(x=x),data=data.frame(x=x))+geom_density()`

`qplot(sample=x)` should be the same as `ggplot(aes(sample=x),data=data.frame(x=x))+stat_qq()`

and so on. 

But the previous behavior of showing nothing is preferable than writing out `NULL`.

@thomasp85 This is an unexpected change introduced in v3.2.0 (due to my carelessness, sorry...). Do you think reverting this needs to be included in v3.2.1? If so, it would be easy to revert the [related changes](https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/pull/2936/files#diff-7c50e6483f96a34bf461315f0d5e818d), though it's not a true fix.
I think we should include it... can you make a PR?
Sure, I will send PRs to master and to v3.2.1-rc.
just to v3.2.1-rc... It will be merged into master once released
Ah, thanks. I got it.
