node.title: axis.line.x not working

node.body:
As you can see in the reprex, below, I can add `theme(axis.line.x = element_line(colour = "black", size = 3)` to your chart with your theme and it works, so I think it's something having to do with the theme composition.

Could you try to make a more minimal reproducible example? _i.e._ isolate the part that isn't working — things like fill colours etc. aren't relevant for the x-axis line. It'll be easier to troubleshoot that way.

Thanks
``` r
library(ggplot2)                                           #create graph
library(ggthemes)                                          #create graph
library(plyr)                                              #factor names                 

#dataset
df <- mtcars
df$cyl <- as.factor(df$cyl)
df$am <- as.factor(df$am)
df$am <- revalue(df$am, c("0"="Automatic", "1"="Manual"))

#define color set; middenblauw, donkerblauw, geel, rood, oranje, donkergroen, lichtblauw, lichtgrijs, donkergrijs
uwvPalet <- c("#0078D2","#003282","#C4D600","#BE0028","#F08C00","#687A00","#B9E2FF","#B9E2FF","#999999")

#generating new theme
theme_uwv <- 
  function(base_size = 22,                                                                 #general font size
           base_family = ""){                                                              #general font type
    theme_hc(base_size = base_size,                                                      #basic theme to start from
             base_family = base_family)   %+replace%
      theme(axis.title.x = element_blank(),                                             #no axis titles
            axis.title.y = element_blank(),
            axis.text = element_text(color = rgb(0, 0, 0,                               #axis text labels
                                                 maxColorValue = 255), size = rel(0.5)),
            axis.ticks = element_blank(),                                               #no axis ticks                                      
            axis.line.x = element_line(colour="black", size = 3),
            legend.title = element_blank(),                                             #no legend title
            legend.text = element_text(color = "black", size = 12,face = "plain"),      #legend text labels
            legend.text.align = 0.5,                                                    #legend text alignment
            legend.spacing.x = unit(0.2, 'cm'),                                         #spacing between legend categories
            panel.grid.major = element_line(rgb(105, 105, 105,maxColorValue = 255),     #only major grid lines
                                            linetype = "solid"),   
            plot.title = element_text(color = rgb(0, 120, 210, maxColorValue = 255),    #titles and subtitles are added in the powerpoint presentation. However, if you do want to include them in your graph, these are the UWV standards
                                      size = 26, face = "bold", hjust = -0.05), 
            plot.subtitle = element_text(color = rgb(0, 120, 210, maxColorValue = 255),
                                         size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = -0.05),
            complete = TRUE
      )
  }

#add default colour set
theme_uwv <- list(theme_uwv(), scale_fill_manual(values = uwvPalet))

# Grouped bar plot
ggplot(df, aes(fill = cyl, x = am, y = mpg)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.9)) +
  theme_uwv +
  theme(axis.line.x = element_line(colour = "black", size = 3))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/x2e3sRs.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Yeah, so if I comment out the parts of the theme _below_ where you set the x-axis line, it works fine. So that might be a good starting off point for you:
``` r
library(ggplot2)                                           #create graph
library(ggthemes)                                          #create graph
library(plyr)                                              #factor names                 

#dataset
df <- mtcars
df$cyl <- as.factor(df$cyl)
df$am <- as.factor(df$am)
df$am <- revalue(df$am, c("0"="Automatic", "1"="Manual"))

#define color set; middenblauw, donkerblauw, geel, rood, oranje, donkergroen, lichtblauw, lichtgrijs, donkergrijs
uwvPalet <- c("#0078D2","#003282","#C4D600","#BE0028","#F08C00","#687A00","#B9E2FF","#B9E2FF","#999999")

#generating new theme
theme_uwv <- 
  function(base_size = 22,                                                                 #general font size
           base_family = ""){                                                              #general font type
    theme_hc(base_size = base_size,                                                      #basic theme to start from
             base_family = base_family)   %+replace%
      theme(axis.title.x = element_blank(),                                             #no axis titles
            axis.title.y = element_blank(),
            axis.text = element_text(color = rgb(0, 0, 0,                               #axis text labels
                                                 maxColorValue = 255), size = rel(0.5)),
            axis.ticks = element_blank(),                                               #no axis ticks                                      
            axis.line.x = element_line(colour="black", size = 3)
            # legend.title = element_blank(),                                             #no legend title
            # legend.text = element_text(color = "black", size = 12,face = "plain"),      #legend text labels
            # legend.text.align = 0.5,                                                    #legend text alignment
            # legend.spacing.x = unit(0.2, 'cm'),                                         #spacing between legend categories
            # panel.grid.major = element_line(rgb(105, 105, 105,maxColorValue = 255),     #only major grid lines
            #                                 linetype = "solid"),   
            # plot.title = element_text(color = rgb(0, 120, 210, maxColorValue = 255),    #titles and subtitles are added in the powerpoint presentation. However, if you do want to include them in your graph, these are the UWV standards
            #                           size = 26, face = "bold", hjust = -0.05), 
            # plot.subtitle = element_text(color = rgb(0, 120, 210, maxColorValue = 255),
            #                              size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = -0.05),
            # complete = TRUE
      )
  }

#add default colour set
theme_uwv <- list(theme_uwv(), scale_fill_manual(values = uwvPalet))

# Grouped bar plot
ggplot(df, aes(fill = cyl, x = am, y = mpg)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.9)) +
  theme_uwv
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/5dzT9QQ.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Hello batpigandme  , yes, thank you, it seemed to have to do with the 

COMPLETE = TRUE

line. Still, the horizontal line that is now visible is not at the same height as is the y=0 intercept with the x-axis. I have searched a little bit into the arguments for the element_line function, but there seems to be no way to adjust it. Do you know of a smart way to do this?

The location of the black line is determined by y axis expansion. Since this is a question about normal ggplot2 usage, please ask over at https://community.rstudio.com. The issue tracker is for problems with the ggplot2 code itself.

node.title: Jitterdodge and text= aesthetic

node.body: Please provide a reproducible example, and please use the [reprex package.](https://reprex.tidyverse.org/articles/articles/magic-reprex.html)

Here it is -

``` r
library(ggplot2)
district_density <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/plotly/datasets/master/district_density.csv",
                             stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
district_density$cluster <- factor(district_density$cluster, levels=c("Pure urban", "Urban-suburban mix", "Dense suburban", "Sparse suburban", "Rural-suburban mix", "Pure rural"))
district_density$region <- factor(district_density$region, levels=c("West", "South", "Midwest", "Northeast"))
ggplot(district_density,aes(x=cluster, y=dem_margin, colour=region, text=paste("district: ", cd_code))) +
  geom_point(position=position_jitterdodge(), alpha=0.5) +
  geom_hline(yintercept=0) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = -30, hjust = 0.1),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
  labs(title = "Democratic performance in the 2018 House elections, by region and density",
       x = "Density Index from CityLab",
       y = "Democratic Margin of Victory/Defeat") +
  theme(text = element_text(family = 'Fira Sans'))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/2T1sv3r.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

You need to specify `group`, otherwise the grouping would be the combinations of all discrete variables; `cluster`, `region` and `paste("district: ", cd_code)`.

For future reference, please ask this kind of questions on RStudio Community or SO first. I guess you would have got nicer answer there more quickly.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
district_density <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/plotly/datasets/master/district_density.csv",
                             stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
district_density$cluster <- factor(district_density$cluster, levels=c("Pure urban", "Urban-suburban mix", "Dense suburban", "Sparse suburban", "Rural-suburban mix", "Pure rural"))
district_density$region <- factor(district_density$region, levels=c("West", "South", "Midwest", "Northeast"))
ggplot(district_density,aes(x=cluster, y=dem_margin, colour=region, text=paste("district: ", cd_code), group = paste(cluster, region))) +
  geom_point(position=position_jitterdodge(), alpha=0.5) +
  geom_hline(yintercept=0) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = -30, hjust = 0.1),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
  labs(title = "Democratic performance in the 2018 House elections, by region and density",
       x = "Density Index from CityLab",
       y = "Democratic Margin of Victory/Defeat")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/F5cMZfI.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-27 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Minimal reprex:

``` r
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(2)
d <- data.frame(
  x = 1,
  y = runif(90),
  g1 = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), each = 30),
  g2 = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 30)
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y, colour = g1)) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y), position = position_jitterdodge(seed = 0))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/9RoerCQ.png)

``` r

ggplot(d, aes(x, y, colour = g1, text = g2)) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y), position = position_jitterdodge(seed = 0))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/MX3wqom.png)

``` r

ggplot(d, aes(x, y, colour = g1, text = g2, group = paste(x, g1))) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y), position = position_jitterdodge(seed = 0))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/IqUTxFW.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-27 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

node.title: Sizing geom_sf point data with variable containing NAs

node.body:
Hmm, this change (I'm not sure if we call this a "regression") seems introduced in v3.2.0... The code used to work before:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggplot2':
#>   method         from 
#>   [.quosures     rlang
#>   c.quosures     rlang
#>   print.quosures rlang
packageVersion("ggplot2")
#> [1] '3.1.1'

nc <- sf::st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"), quiet = TRUE)
nc_3857 <- sf::st_transform(nc, "+init=epsg:3857")

nc_3857$mid <- sf::st_centroid(nc_3857$geometry)

nc_3857$AREA[10] <- NA

ggplot(nc_3857) +
  geom_sf(aes(geometry = mid, size = AREA))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/1VQXoBv.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-13 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

The error comes from here in `sf_grob()`:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/fc8f7d528995ff83716177def4c332187827e0b9/R/geom-sf.R#L159-L162

Since `grid::gpar()` accepts a single `NA`, containing `NA`s hadn't become a problem until `sf_grob()` got vectorized by #3164.

``` r
grid::gpar(fontsize = NA)
#> named list()
grid::gpar(fontsize = c(1, NA))
#> Error in checkNA("fontsize"): mixture of missing and non-missing values for fontsize
```

<sup>Created on 2019-08-13 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Now that it's vectorized, it seems we need to replace `NA`s on ggplot2's side to let it be drawn. But, I'm not sure if `NA`-size points should be drawn or not. Maybe it should not, similarly to   https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/issues/2757#issuecomment-423987868?

> But, I'm not sure if `NA`-size points should be drawn or not.

Now I'm sure it should not. Probably, `GeomSf` needs to have its own `handle_na()` because `non_missing_aes` varies, depending the type of the geometry.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/geom-.r#L67-L72

> `GeomSf` needs to have its own `handle_na()`

Sorry, I was wrong here. It seems `GeomSf` should always have `non_missing_aes()` as `sf_grob()` always passes `fontsize`.

node.title: geom_boxplot using both color and (group or discrete x) aeses

node.body:
> the workaround represents the correct approach?

Yes. It's not a "workaround", but how ggplot2's grouping works.

When you don't specify `group` aesthetic explicitly, ggplot2 guesses the grouping structure from other variables (this time it was `colour`). But, when you specify `group` variable, you need to specify (or calculate) `group` that splits data into actual groups you want; it's you who is responsible for concatenating the two variables.

This doc might help: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/aes_group_order.html

Here's a simpler reprex.

``` r
library(tibble)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(10)
d <- tibble(
  group_x = rep(1:2, each = 10),
  group_y = rep(1:2, times = 10),
  y = group_y + runif(20)
)

ggplot(d, aes(group_x, y, color = factor(group_y))) + 
  geom_boxplot(aes(group = group_x)) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/CKLyJJ2.png)

``` r

ggplot(d, aes(group_x, y, color = factor(group_y))) + 
  geom_boxplot(aes(group = paste(group_x, group_y))) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/UFqHUAN.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-17 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

(As a side note, it might be a bit confusing that `StatBoxplot` (and other Stats than `StatIdentity`) silently ignores non-unique variables (`ggplot2:::uniquecols()`). Maybe we can show some warning...?)

node.title: facet_grid() errors with the dev version of tibble

node.body:
Now I think this is due to the change in the dev version of tibble, and it errors on all cases except when the number of rows equals to the number of cols.

``` r
library(ggplot2, lib.loc = "~/R-dev/")

d <- data.frame(
  x = c("a", "b", "c"),
  y = c("X", "Y", "Z")
)

ggplot(d, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_grid(vars(x), vars(y))
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be recycled to length 3. Only vectors of length
#> one or of the same length can be recycled.
```

It seems error comes from here:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/facet-grid-.r#L279

``` r
library(tibble)

d <- tibble(x = 1, y = 1)
d[] <- lapply(d[], as.factor)
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be recycled to length 1. Only vectors of length
#> one or of the same length can be recycled.
```

<sup>Created on 2019-08-21 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

node.title: element_text size using vector

node.body:
Would you mind turning this into a [reprex](http://reprex.tidyverse.org/) (short for minimal **repr**oducible **ex**ample)? It's especially helpful for ggplot2, since it automatically generates and uploads the plots (or lack thereof), which makes it much easier to go through at a glance.

If you've never heard of a reprex before, you might want to start by reading the tidyverse.org [help page](https://www.tidyverse.org/help/).

Right now the best way to install reprex is:
```r
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("tidyverse/reprex")
```
If you run into problems with access to your clipboard, you can specify an outfile for the reprex, and then copy and paste (or drag and drop) the contents here.

```r
reprex::reprex(input = "fruits_stringdist.R", outfile = "fruits_stringdist.md")
```

Thanks

Thank you for the hint with the clipboard

``` r
library(tidyverse)
library(tibble)
ds <- mtcars %>%
  rownames_to_column() %>%
  select(car = rowname, mpg)

ds_size = rep(8, nrow(ds))
ds_size[10] <- 12

ds %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = car, y = mpg)) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = ds_size))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/Z3lppHY.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Hmm, I get the same results you've shown above with the dev version.

Here it is with ggplot2 **3.0.0**
``` r
library(tidyverse)

ds <- mtcars %>%
  rownames_to_column() %>%
  select(car = rowname, mpg)

ds_size = rep(8, nrow(ds))
ds_size[10] <- 12

ds %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = car, y = mpg)) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = ds_size))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/3Vwvmpk.png)

---------

And below is with **3.1.1**

``` r
library(tidyverse)

ds <- mtcars %>%
  rownames_to_column() %>%
  select(car = rowname, mpg)

ds_size = rep(8, nrow(ds))
ds_size[10] <- 12

ds %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = car, y = mpg)) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = ds_size))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/KoVsC34.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

It seems the element takes the sum of the values as margin. BTW, is `element_*()` supposed to accept vectors? I've seen this kind of tricks somewhere several times, but I guess none of the official docs refer to this.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(x = letters[1:10], y = 1:10, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

f <- function(n) {
  ggplot(d) +
    geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = rep(8, n)))
}

f(1)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/LCKQJyO.png)

``` r
f(10)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/NMopmap.png)

``` r
f(100)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/E0e0bjM.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

@batpigandme Sorry, I forgot the geometry in my reprex. Here is a new one

``` r
library(ggplot2)

ds <- data.frame(
  car = rownames(mtcars),
  mpg = mtcars$mpg
)

ds_size = rep(8, nrow(ds))
ds_size[10] <- 12

ggplot(ds, ggplot2::aes(x = car, y = mpg)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(size = ds_size))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/7ooIwMs.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

@yutannihilation I cannot remember where I got the hint, but using a vector for face still works

``` r
library(ggplot2)

ds <- data.frame(
  car = rownames(mtcars),
  mpg = mtcars$mpg
)

ds_face = rep("plain", nrow(ds))
ds_face[10] <- "bold"

ggplot(ds, ggplot2::aes(x = car, y = mpg)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_text(face = ds_face))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/r9GlxJt.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Thank you

I'm not a big fan of setting text parameters as vectors in this way, mostly because it's unpredictable when it works and when it doesn't. It works for axes but it doesn't work for legends, for internal technical reasons that are not visible to the enduser.

Having said that, I don't understand why this specific example fails. We should track down the cause, because it suggests something weird is going on with the `size` argument.
Thanks, agreed. Let's see what's happening here.

Here is what I *think* is happening. (I don't quite understand yet why it only happens for font size, and not for font face, so maybe I'm wrong.)

This line returns now a vector of descent values rather than just one value:
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/1ae034ee6f5c669f497c96d3258cf2ca13907953/R/margins.R#L69
``` r
ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", rep(10, 5), 1)
#> [1] 0.0292290581597222inches 0.0292290581597222inches
#> [3] 0.0292290581597222inches 0.0292290581597222inches
#> [5] 0.0292290581597222inches
```

<sup>Created on 2019-08-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

This vector results in vectors `text_width` and `text_height`, which are given to `add_margins()` here:
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/1ae034ee6f5c669f497c96d3258cf2ca13907953/R/margins.R#L197-L205

And the `add_margins()` function then build layouts assuming `width` and `height` are single values rather than vectors:
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/1ae034ee6f5c669f497c96d3258cf2ca13907953/R/margins.R#L115-L121

Again, this doesn't yet fully explain what exactly is happening, but I think it's on the right track. Importantly, it's based on a line that was changed with the latest release:
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/commit/f5a88a71e7b60b6531ef6c4a936370b5e3c4ef92#diff-004d6436e77ba3e9705ab23890dace32

The previous function `descentDetails()` produced the wrong results, but it didn't create vectors.

Thanks. For facet strips, it seems we do the right thing to pass a single `height` and `width` to `add_margins()` even when `height` and/or `width` is a vector.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/labeller.r#L608-L631

edit:

But, facet strips doesn't accept variable sizes...

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(x = letters[1:10], y = 1:10, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
  facet_wrap(vars(x)) +
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size = 1:10 * 5))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/AXyWeWj.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I made a PR that seems to fix the problem, though I still don't fully understand how exactly things go wrong. #3493

Confirmed #3493 fixes the issue. But, I too don't understand how the things are supposed to work here...

Is `font_descent()` really intended to work with multiple `size`s? I see it returns the same values for different sizes in the vector (Does this happen only on Windows?).

``` r
ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", 10, 1)
#> [1] 0.03125inches
ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", c(10, 10), 1)
#> [1] 0.03125inches 0.03125inches

ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", c(10, 20), 1)
#> [1] 0.03125inches 0.03125inches
ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", 1:10 * 10, 1)
#>  [1] 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches
#>  [6] 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches 0.03125inches

# probably the cache works wrong here...
ggplot2:::font_descent("", "plain", 1:10 * 20, 1)
#>  [1] 0.03125inches            0.03125inches           
#>  [3] 0.03125inches            0.03125inches           
#>  [5] 0.03125inches            0.0520833333333333inches
#>  [7] 0.0520833333333333inches 0.0520833333333333inches
#>  [9] 0.0520833333333333inches 0.0520833333333333inches
```

<sup>Created on 2019-08-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

I made a new PR that simplifies `font_descent()` by only returning the first result. I'm Ok with that, because even if it returned multiple results correctly the `title_spec()` function wouldn't know what to do with them.

(Just a note to self)

> It seems the element takes the sum of the values as margin.

This behaviour comes from here; `widthDetails()` and `heightDetails()` takes the sum of the widths and heights of a `titleGrob`.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/margins.R#L214-L216
But why do we see the behavior only for font size but not for example for font face? I still don't get that.

Curiously, it seems another bug... Here, `gp$fontface` is passed to `title_spec()`, but `gp` doesn't contains `fontface`.

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/margins.R#L69

e.g.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(x = letters[1:10], y = 1:10, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 30, face = rep("plain", 10)))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/CjbHeTy.png)

``` r

ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 30, family = rep("", 10)))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/WKj5YqU.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

It seems `gpar()` treats `fontface` differently than other parameters.

``` r
grid::gpar(
  fontsize = NULL,
  col = NULL,
  fontfamily = NULL,
  fontface = NULL,
  lineheight = NULL
)
#> $fontface
#> NULL
```

<sup>Created on 2019-08-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

As `gp` keeps `fontface = NULL`, it removes `fontface` from `element_gp` at `modify_list(element_gp, gp)` here:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/theme-elements.r#L209-L219
Ok, I see it now. The strange handling of `fontface` in `gpar()` is actually one of my number one pet peeves. It takes so much effort to work around it. I'm constantly battling with it in gridtext.

I have tested the different parameters for `element_text()` in the reprex above using vectors.
It is working for: `face`, `colour`, `hjust` and `vjust` - whereas the font int hjust did not render well
it is not working for: `size`, `angle` and `family`

> it is not working for: `size`, `angle` and `family`

Opps, thanks...

@clauswilke 
#3493 doesn't fix `angle`. We need to consider the case when `angle` is a vector here:

https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/b8420241309c8eea00d7086002c01cdf38a50eac/R/margins.R#L74-L75
Ok. I think we should just ignore all but the first angle. I expect using multiple angles along the axis never worked (but I've never tried it).

Agreed.

> I expect using multiple angles along the axis never worked (but I've never tried it).

I confirmed it didn't work at the time of v3.1.1.

A bit late to this. I honestly think we shouldn’t allow vectorised input in `element_text()`. As mentioned the behaviour is unpredictable but when it works by chance it gives the impression that it is a feature.

There are valid obscure reason for the weirdness of the `fontface` element in `gpar` and that is not going to change. For performance reasons the gpar list is treated specially in the grid C internals and fiddling around with it can mess things up unexpectedly
Do you remember how many revdep packages were broken when you tried to stop support vectorised input? https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/pull/3237

Sounds like it was just a single package but I honestly can’t remember. I’d propose that we catch this at the `element_*()` and throw a warning so that it is clear what is not allowed/supported. We will never support this behaviour fully anyway
OK, if it's just one or two packages, I agree with the idea of warning. It sounds the right approach.

Let's not say "never". My `element_markdown()` from ggtext calculates margins, descents, grob extents, etc. correctly for vectorized input (not that the example necessarily shows that).

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(ggtext)

d <- data.frame(x = letters[1:16], y = 1:16, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_markdown(size = 3*c(5:12, 11:4)))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/CoGFTHm.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-24 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Also, I feel that the whole `title_spec()` code is a bit of a mess and should be replaced at some point.

I'll add a warning at the drawing stage, so we get a warning exactly where the code receives input it can't handle. This way, if at some point in the future we have more general support for vectorized input, the warning will simply disappear.

I can only agree with you on `title_spec()`. What I mean with *never* is that while the `element_*()` might work vectorised it will depend on the context in which they are called. Your `element_markdown()` will not behave as if it was vectorised for strip texts so having it work that way for axis text will only confuse. 

On a deeper level, I really don’t like that the theming can become tightly coupled with the exact plot, eg your example will only work with plots that have 16 x-axis labels. I don’t think that should be allowed

I think @thomasp85’s reasoning is compelling: a theme should not be tied to a specific plot, and any use of vectors should be considered an unsupported hack. 

That said, I think people we be unhappy if we remove this without warning so I think it’ll have to go through a deprecation cycle.
I agree we should deprecate it carefully, but we should at the least not build out support for the hack🙂
FWIW, I think most of the use cases for this hack can be solved properly using `element_markdown()`

I've updated my PR. How is this?

``` r
library(ggplot2)

d <- data.frame(x = letters[1:16], y = 1:16, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x, y)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 3*c(5:12, 11:4)))
#> Warning: Vectorized input to `element_text()` is not officially supported.
#> Results may be unexpected or may change in future versions of ggplot2.
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/yUlei8k.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-25 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

> `#> Results may be unexpected or may change in future versions of ggplot2.`

If we agree to put the vectorized behavior into the deprecation cycle, I think we should choose a bit stronger words to discourage the usage.

(Just a side comment)

> On a deeper level, I really don’t like that the theming can become tightly coupled with the exact plot

I too felt so, but, after some thinking, now I'm not sure if I can fully agree with this. Leaving the technical details aside, a theme *can* be tightly coupled with the exact plot; For example, it depends on the length of labels how much angle we should rotate the labels. Using the analogy of HTML and CSS, they are designed to separate theming from the data, but, in practice, elaborated CSSs are so tightly coupled with the exact HTMLs that they cannot be reused easily.

I don’t think your example is exactly fitting. What I’m talking about is a deep “technical” coupling — not an aesthetic one. True, label rotation may only look good with packed labels, but there are no technical requirements of the plot that means that a plot will fail to render with certain rotation settings.

> there are no technical requirements of the plot that means that a plot will fail to render with certain rotation settings.

Ah, I see.

node.title: grouping in geom_boxplot broken after upgrading from 3.5.2 to 3.6.1

node.body: I can make both data and full script available, but this is an ongoing research project with personally identifiable data, so I cannot just post it here.
here is the input data for the box plot at least: [stats.txt](https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/files/3526718/stats.txt)
you should make a fully reproducible example with a dataset such as ``cars``, and even better use ``reprex``.

This is listed as a breaking change in the [3.2.0 release notes](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggplot2/news/news.html) (issue #3316). 

While the plot may have worked for you, it was using code whose behavior was undefined. To fix your plot, you'll have to define a `group` aesthetic that has a unique value for each boxplot that should be drawn.

Problem is that the error message is very unclear and misleading, as I clearly did set a group = in the code, and the release notes also do not specify what stopped working or how the input is supposed to be given now.

The error message states exactly what the problem is: "Can't draw more than one boxplot per group." You will have to assign a grouping variable that has a unique value for each boxplot you want to see drawn. If you're not sure what that means or how to achieve this, I suggest you ask over on the RStudio forums or on Stackoverflow.

node.title: Feature Request - Wouldn't it be cool if ggplot2 recognized `dplyr::group_by()`?

node.body:
I don't think ggplot2 can be `group_by()`-aware, You might feel it's convenient if it behaves differently, but someone might feel it's confusing. I'm sure it would break many existing codes (e.g. https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/issues/2378)

That said, I feel there's some need for a `group`-aware Stat in ggplot2. I see this kind of requests and questions are posted periodically.

node.title: Confusing behavior when mapping some variables to aes(size) in geom_point and geom_path

node.body:
Yes, it behaves as intended. If you map `size` via `aes()`, then you also have to define an appropriate scale, and if you don't do that then ggplot2 will make one up, and that scale may not look the way you were expecting.

If you have further questions on this topic, I suggest you post them on the RStudio forums or on Stackoverflow.

node.title: geom_curve for large dataset degrades ggplot2 performance/crash

node.body:
For a dataset of this size, please make a reprex with computationally generated data rather than a gigantic dput dump.

I can't reproduce your crash with a similarly sized data set, but it's clear that you're misusing the ggplot2 API and that causes the slow rendering. You're drawing 10000 arrows and 10000 text labels on top of each other. Once that is fixed, rendering is reasonably fast.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

df <- data.frame(trans = 10*rnorm(10000))
                                  
ggplot(df, aes(x = trans)) + 
  geom_density() + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(df$trans), col = "green", size =2) +
  geom_curve(data = data.frame(x = 1), aes(x = 10, y = .15, xend = 4.4, yend = .18),
             colour = "#555555", size=0.5, curvature = 0.3,
             arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.03, "npc"))) +
  geom_text(data = data.frame(x = 1), aes(x= 9, y = .15, label= paste0("Average number of items\n per transaction is: ",
            round(mean(mtcars$mpg),2)), colour = "blue", family = "Times New Roman")) 
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/pgi57Vg.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-27 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

If you cut and paste the dput dump, you will get the dataset and should be able to reproduce the error. 

Not sure what you mean by 'abuse the api', but I'd appreciate you or someone try and and test because the issue is reproducible. 

FYI - dput dump is reprex.

Not abuse, just misuse. Do you understand the difference between yours and Claus's version of code? I guess [`annotate()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/annotate.html) is what you want.

> FYI - dput dump is reprex.

It can be a reprex, but please try to provide a **minimal** reprex. (I couldn't copy and paste your dump, BTW...)
FWIW, I also wasn't able to copy and paste the `dput()` dump.

Ok, I understand. Here is a reprex data. And hit the same issue again!

```
df <- data.frame(var_name = paste0("V", 1:9825), 
                               trans = sample(1:32, 9825, replace = TRUE))
```

As stated in my original filing. I do not experience the same issue when the data size is small. I used the same script on mtcars. And no problem.

I cannot reproduce your issue with a more recent version of R. You may have to update.

And regardless, please fix your code so you don't draw thousands of annotations.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

df <- data.frame(var_name = paste0("V", 1:9825), 
                 trans = sample(1:32, 9825, replace = TRUE))

# incorrect code, draws 9825 annotations
ggplot(df, aes(x = trans)) + 
  geom_density() + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(df$trans), col = "green", size =2) +
  geom_curve(aes(x = 10, y = .15, xend = 4.4, yend = .18),
             colour = "#555555", size=0.5, curvature = 0.3,
             arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.03, "npc"))) +
  geom_text(aes(x= 9, y = .15, label= paste0("Average number of items\n per transaction is: ",
                                             round(mean(mtcars$mpg),2)), colour = "blue", family = "Times New Roman")) 
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/JPZsMdM.png)

``` r

# correct code, draws 1 annotation
ggplot(df, aes(x = trans)) + 
  geom_density() + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(df$trans), col = "green", size =2) +
  geom_curve(data = data.frame(x = 1), aes(x = 10, y = .15, xend = 4.4, yend = .18),
             colour = "#555555", size=0.5, curvature = 0.3,
             arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.03, "npc"))) +
  geom_text(data = data.frame(x = 1), aes(x= 9, y = .15, label= paste0("Average number of items\n per transaction is: ",
                                                                       round(mean(mtcars$mpg),2)), colour = "blue", family = "Times New Roman")) 
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/pg6zfty.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-08-28 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
The R version maybe the problem. There is no problem with the code. It would be helpful, if you point what part of my code is the issue. Thanks.
Please carefully compare the two code versions I have posted in my previous comment.

node.title: Multiple factor columns, same aesthetic: levels reordered if NAs present

node.body:
The levels matters only on the order of a variable within a layer. Merging them is done in a character way. For example:

``` r
library(tidyverse)

lvls <- c("b", "a")
df <- tibble(x = rep(1:3, each = 3),
             fct1 = factor("a", levels = lvls),
             fct2 = factor("b", levels = lvls),
             y = rnorm(9))

ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = fct1), size = 6) +
  geom_point(aes(color = fct2), size = 4)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/oIazurD.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-11 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

So, the problem is the difference of the actual values in each layer, and `NA` matters here because a discrete scale attempts to include `NA` by default. You can specify `na.translate = FALSE` to avoid this, though.

> Unlike continuous scales, discrete scales can easily show missing values, and do so by default. If you want to remove missing values from a discrete scale, specify `na.translate = FALSE`.
 (https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/discrete_scale.html)

``` r
library(tidyverse)
lvls <- c("b", "a", "c")
df <- tibble(x = rep(1:3, each = 3),
             fct1 = factor(rep(lvls, 3), levels = lvls),
             fct2 = factor(rep(c(lvls[c(2, 3)], NA), 3), levels = lvls),
             y = rnorm(9))

p1 <- ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = fct1), size = 4)

p2 <- ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = fct2), size = 4)

patchwork::wrap_plots(p1, p2)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/qWrq4FQ.png)

``` r

ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y, color = fct1)) +
  geom_point(size = 6) +
  geom_point(aes(color = fct2), size = 4) +
  scale_colour_hue(na.translate = FALSE)
#> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values (geom_point).
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/29ja5MI.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-11 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

node.title: Feature request: a quick and dirty custom legend

node.body:
I'm not sure if fully manual legends are something that we're likely to develop soon, however `override.aes` provides enough manual control that, combining it with manual scale breaks, I do think there's a way to get what you are looking for in this plot:

``` r
library("ggplot2")
dat <- data.frame(Year=2016,
                  Fleet=c(rep(c("Artisanal","Industrial"),times=2)), 
                  set = rep(c("Predicted","Observed"),each=2),
                  q5=c(0.8,1.1,NA,NA),
                  q50=c(9.1,14.1,0,0),
                  q95=c(40,50,NA,NA))

dat$set <- as.character(dat$set)
pal <- c("#7bbcb0", "#3a7c89")
pd <- position_dodge(0.2)

ggplot(
  dat,
  aes(x = Year,
      y = q50,
      shape = factor(Fleet),
      colour = factor(Fleet),
      fill = ifelse(set == "Predicted", factor(Fleet), set))
) + 
  geom_linerange(aes(ymin = q5, ymax = q95), position = pd, lwd = 1.1) +
  geom_point(size = 4,position = pd) +
  scale_shape_manual("Fleet", values = c(24, 21)) +
  scale_colour_manual("Fleet", values = pal) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    "set",
    values = c(pal, "white"),
    breaks = c(1, 2),
    labels = c("Predicted", "Observed")
  ) +
  guides(
    colour = "none",
    fill = guide_legend(
      override.aes = list(shape = 21, fill = list("black", "white"))
    ),
    shape = guide_legend(
      override.aes = list(fill = pal, colour = pal)
    )
  )
#> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_linerange).
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/efuGtnl.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-03 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

Does this work for your use case?
It wooooooorked! Thank you so much. This works for my purpose! I would not have been able to figure it out without you.

node.title: Feature request: compressed TIFF output from ggsave()

node.body: `ggsave()` passes `...` along to the graphic device and `tiff()` indeed has a `compression` argument that you can use to set a range of compression strategies. You could e.g. do `ggsave(filename="Fig3.tiff", scale=1, width=80, height=60, units="mm", dpi=300, compression = "lzw+p")`. See the documentation for `tiff()` for more compression possibilities

node.title: borders() w/ coord_map()

node.body:
Reprex below. Looks like a coordinate wrapping problem. In any case, for geospatial plotting, it's probably better to move to `geom_sf()`. And to me, `borders()` seems out of scope of ggplot2 proper, and we should consider deprecating it or at least upgrading it to use sf.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot() +
  borders() 
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/J1hQB1y.png)

``` r

ggplot() +
  borders() +
  coord_map()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/lcn6FAO.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-14 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

This seems to be caused by the specific projection used by `coord_map()`, which is provided by mapproject. In general, I would recommend against using `coord_map()`, since `coord_sf()` is a much better solution to the same problem.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

# works
ggplot() +
  borders() +
  coord_quickmap()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/d4GodHw.png)

``` r

# works
ggplot() +
  borders() +
  coord_map(projection = "orthographic")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/WljvlJV.png)

``` r

# doesn't work
ggplot() +
  borders() +
  coord_map(projection = "mollweide")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/gM2tO8T.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-14 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
I think I kind of agree that it "seems out of scope of ggplot2 proper".  So I'll use another approach for now.  Thank you for looking into this!

Here is how you can make a world map using the Robinson projection, which is reasonable.

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(rworldmap) # for getMap()
#> Loading required package: sp
#> ### Welcome to rworldmap ###
#> For a short introduction type :   vignette('rworldmap')
library(sf)
#> Linking to GEOS 3.6.1, GDAL 2.1.3, PROJ 4.9.3

world_sf <- st_as_sf(getMap(resolution = "low"))

crs_robin <- "+proj=robin +lat_0=0 +lon_0=0 +x0=0 +y0=0"

ggplot(world_sf) + 
  geom_sf(size = 0.5/.pt) +
  coord_sf(crs = crs_robin)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/MRrRZmP.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-15 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

The Winkel Tripel projection would be better, but unfortunately can't be done with a simple projection string. It needs a little more manual work, as shown here:
https://github.com/clauswilke/dataviz/blob/68f455d33eaa2331e3932fde9291803dcf0c989e/coordinate_systems_axes.Rmd#L620-L661

You can see the difference between Robinson and Winkel Tripel here:
https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/coordinate-systems-axes.html#fig:worldmap-four-projections

node.title: Jitter doesn't match for geom_point() and geom_line() unless data sorted

node.body: There is no real way around this... `geom_line()` sorts its data to make sure the line flows in one direction. This means the jittering is calculated on a particular ordering of the data and can only be replicated in other geoms if the order is the same

```r
library(ggplot2)
library(ggforce)
df <- data.frame(x = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),

ggplot(df, aes(z, x)) +

 ```

node.title: nudge_x and nudge_y in geom_text with facet_wrap issue

node.body:
This type of question is better suited for the RStudio forums or stackoverflow.com. The ggplot2 issue tracker is not meant as a place for user support.

In a nutshell, though, you can either calculate appropriate `nudge_x` and `nudge_y` values for the respective subsets of your data or you can use `hjust` and `vjust`.

node.title: geom_text and scale_y_log10 issue

node.body:
This is because of the `nudge_y` argument. It gets applied to the transformed data which means that it's effect will become non-linear (and potentially huge). In general the `nudge_*` arguments are pretty crude and should only get applied to linear transformed scales.

You can get something a bit nicer-looking by using `coord_trans(y = "log")` instead of `scaly_y_log()` but then you'll have a non-linear nudging:

```r
ggplot(sampledata,
       aes(x = Date, y = Value)) +
  geom_line(size = 0.75) +
  geom_hline(threshold, mapping = aes(yintercept = Value), linetype = 'longdash', color = 'grey30') +
  geom_text(threshold, mapping = aes(x = Date, y = Value, label = Note), 
            inherit.aes = FALSE, nudge_y = 50) +
  coord_trans(y = 'log')
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1775316/65749179-ef74b500-e105-11e9-88ef-06fbd690ef96.png)

As your text is all a single line the best course of action would probably be to set a negative `vjust` on the text (be aware that this trick will lead to different offsetting if the text have differences in height)

```r
ggplot(sampledata,
       aes(x = Date, y = Value)) +
  geom_line(size = 0.75) +
  geom_hline(threshold, mapping = aes(yintercept = Value), linetype = 'longdash', color = 'grey30') +
  geom_text(threshold, mapping = aes(x = Date, y = Value, label = Note), 
            inherit.aes = FALSE, vjust = -.5) +
  scale_y_log10()
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1775316/65749378-41b5d600-e106-11e9-8842-3900124d9d3d.png)

node.title: stat_summary with geom = "boxplot" error even when group aesthetic is supplied

node.body:
It may look like the first plot works and the second doesn't, but in fact both plots have the same problem. Your `custombox1()` function creates one row per original data point, not one row per group. Thus, you're asking ggplot to draw one errorbar/boxplot per original data point. In the first case, all these errorbars are plotted on top of one another. In the second case, you get an error.

If you have further questions on this topic, the RStudio forums or stackoverflow.com would be more appropriate venues. ggplot works as expected.

``` r
library(ggplot2)

custombox1 <- function(y){
  d <- data.frame(ymin=quantile(y,0.025),
             lower=quantile(y,0.25),
             middle=quantile(y,0.5),
             upper=quantile(y,0.75),
             ymax=quantile(y,0.975),
             y=y,
             width=0.5,
             row.names = NULL)
  d[1, ]
}

ggplot(
  data = data.frame(x = sample(letters, 200, replace = TRUE), y = runif(200)),
  mapping = aes(group = x, x = x, y = y)
) +
  stat_summary(fun.data = custombox1, geom = "errorbar") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = custombox1, geom = "boxplot")
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/UHxzYiA.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-09-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>
Thank you so much!

node.title: boxplot computation fails when setting scale limits

node.body:
I believe the issue is more fundamental than scale limits. Consider the following code:
``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(nycflights13)

ggplot(data = weather, mapping = aes(x = factor(month), y = temp)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```
Using `ggplot2_3.2.1` yields

![](https://i.imgur.com/2X7moIY.png)

whereas using `ggplot2_3.2.1.9000` yields 

![](https://i.imgur.com/o0ZCeQ3.png)
along with the same error message as above:

``` r
#> Warning: Computation failed in `stat_boxplot()`:
#> missing values and NaN's not allowed if 'na.rm' is FALSE
```
cc @ismayc

I think I found the problem. It's in this line:
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/10fa0014d6be81a7e641b8c2c3b48e1df1b7e2f5/R/stat-boxplot.r#L55

It should read `vars = "y"`.

Reprex:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(rlang)
library(nycflights13)

# doesn't work
ggplot(data = weather, mapping = aes(x = factor(month), y = temp)) +
  geom_boxplot()
#> Warning: Computation failed in `stat_boxplot()`:
#> missing values and NaN's not allowed if 'na.rm' is FALSE
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/DQUkDdi.png)

``` r

# fix setup_data() function of StatBoxplot
StatBoxplot$setup_data <- function(data, params) {
  data <- ggplot2:::flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
  data$x <- data$x %||% 0
  data <- ggplot2:::remove_missing(
    data,
    na.rm = FALSE,
    vars = "y",
    name = "stat_boxplot"
  )
  flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
}

# now it works
ggplot(data = weather, mapping = aes(x = factor(month), y = temp)) +
  geom_boxplot()
#> Warning: Removed 1 rows containing missing values (stat_boxplot).
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/AnDZo6b.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-10-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

cc @thomasp85

Thomas, while we're at it, is this line correct, or should it read `na.rm = params$na.rm`?
https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/blob/10fa0014d6be81a7e641b8c2c3b48e1df1b7e2f5/R/stat-boxplot.r#L54

It looks like with the current settings it's impossible to suppress the warning about missing values.
``` r
library(ggplot2)
library(rlang)
library(nycflights13)

# fix setup_data() function of StatBoxplot
StatBoxplot$setup_data <- function(data, params) {
  data <- ggplot2:::flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
  data$x <- data$x %||% 0
  data <- ggplot2:::remove_missing(
    data,
    na.rm = FALSE,
    vars = "y",
    name = "stat_boxplot"
  )
  flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
}

# warning doesn't get suppressed
ggplot(data = weather, mapping = aes(x = factor(month), y = temp)) +
  geom_boxplot(na.rm = TRUE)
#> Warning: Removed 1 rows containing missing values (stat_boxplot).
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/tD3XfQa.png)

``` r

StatBoxplot$setup_data <- function(data, params) {
  data <- ggplot2:::flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
  data$x <- data$x %||% 0
  data <- ggplot2:::remove_missing(
    data,
    na.rm = params$na.rm,
    vars = "y",
    name = "stat_boxplot"
  )
  flip_data(data, params$flipped_aes)
}

# now the warning gets suppressed
ggplot(data = weather, mapping = aes(x = factor(month), y = temp)) +
  geom_boxplot(na.rm = TRUE)
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/Lnrg819.png)

<sup>Created on 2019-10-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>

@clauswilke I don't know if it was intended that way (hardcoding the `na.rm`). @karawoo do you remember.

As for the cause of the original issue, it is actually much more complicated and is due to the new `x|y` notation in `required_aes` - will figure out a fix
I think hardcoding `na.rm` was just an oversight, I'll fix it
Thank you for fixing this so promptly. I would like to give credit to my student Nouhaila @nouny for finding the error with the `temp` vs `month` boxplot.

node.title: mnormt error preventing tidyverse from loading

node.body:
Might be that you updated your system to something that replaced `gcc6` with something else, but R was using a `mnormt` package that was compiled with a dynamic link to the old `libgfortran` from `gcc6`? 
That seems to be what the error message is saying, and that would also explain how manually installing `mnormt` resolved the issue (i.e., you recompiled the package, linking it to whatever `libgfortran` is available in your current system)
Installing tidyverse seems to bring out a lot of weird package installation bugs. We're working on tools to better diagnose and fix them.
Installing `gcc-gfortran`  package (on CentOS) helped me for installing `mnormt`. For the whole tidyverse I had to install also  `libxml2-devel` for `xml2` package.

Do you have `R_LIBS` set in `.Renviron` or similar?

I think this is a bug in `install.packages()`/`library()`. The root error comes from `library()` - if you attach a package that is already loaded, `library()` compares the package version between the loaded version and the on disk version, and attempts to [unload and reload](https://github.com/wch/r-source/blob/d1f01dc790201e2e40c97e8da45c51c495874ffe/src/library/base/R/library.R#L277-L293).  `library()` is called by [`.test_load_package()`](https://github.com/wch/r-source/blob/89ec1150299f7be62b839d5d5eb46bd9a63653bd/src/library/tools/R/admin.R#L918), which is called by [`install.packages`](https://github.com/wch/r-source/blob/17ea295025dcd71a5834a787c51380a358e7274c/src/library/tools/R/install.R#L1213) as part of a check to ensure the package has been installed somewhere. `.test_load_package()` is run in another R session but not with `--vanilla`.

My hypothesis is that somewhere in the bowels of `library()` a function doesn't pass `lib.loc` along, so it ends up using the version of the package you currently have installed in one place, and the version you're trying to install in another. This is hypothesis is supported by two fixes that work for me:

* Remove `R_LIBS` from my `~/.Renviron`
* Install ggplot2 from CRAN

I think this explains why we each see failures with slightly different packages: I have a dev version of ggplot2 and I'm guessing that @klmr has dev tidyr and @jbromley has dev tibble.

I can reliably reproduce with:

```R
install_github("tidyverse/ggplot2")
packageVersion("ggplot2")

tmp <- tempfile()
dir.create(tmp)
.libPaths(tmp)
install.packages("tidyverse", type = "source")
```

(But note this takes a loooooong time)

> Do you have `R_LIBS` set in `.Renviron` or similar?

No — I just verified this and it’s set neither in `$R_HOME` nor in `$HOME` (nor the test directory). To be on the safe side, I’ve deleted my `$HOME/.Renviron` file (it was obsolete anyway). Also, to verify, inside the test environment, my `.libPaths()` shows only this:

```
[1] "/Users/rudolph/tmp/tinytidy/test-library"
[2] "/usr/local/Cellar/r/3.4.1_1/R.framework/Versions/3.4/Resources/library"
```

… and I have almost no libraries installed in the Framework path beyond the default ones.

And unfortunately for your hypothesis I haven’t got dev tidyr installed *anywhere* (it’s 0.7.1, from CRAN). Same for broom (which my error message also mentions). And for good measure, ggplot2 is also installed from CRAN.
Bummer :( I have no idea what's going wrong for you then, except I'm still fairly certain its `install.packages()` fault.

Hi @hadley and all,
I am having the same issue after the recommended installation `tmp <- tempfile()
dir.create(tmp)
.libPaths(tmp)
install.packages("tidyverse", type = "source")`

It looks like it is common problem. Any suggestions yet?

`> sessionInfo()
R version 3.3.3 (2017-03-06)
Platform: x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0 (64-bit)
Running under: macOS  10.13.3

locale:
[1] en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/C/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8

attached base packages:
[1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     

loaded via a namespace (and not attached):
[1] tools_3.3.3 tcltk_3.3.3`

I was getting the same error, and then specified the library location when loading:

library(stringr,libloc = "LibraryLocation")

Error went away and stringr worked again. Not sure why. Maybe @hadley or someone else has some insight on that.
In case anyone else is looking for a workaround, `devtools::install_cran` was able to install `tidyverse` even when `install.packages` was refusing to due to this issue.

This is still presenting, I have tried pointing to multiple points in CRAN time (through using the microsoft MRAN snapshots). I went back ~ 1 month at 1 week intervals and in all instances it failed.

It seems to fail consistently on ggplot2:

```
Error: package or namespace load failed for ‘tidyverse’:
 .onAttach failed in attachNamespace() for 'tidyverse', details:
  call: value[[3L]](cond)\n  error: Package ‘ggplot2’ version 3.1.0 cannot be unloaded:
 Error in unloadNamespace(package) : namespace ‘ggplot2’ is imported by ‘tidyverse’ so cannot be unloaded
Error: loading failed
Execution halted
```

I have tried this through install.packages("tidyverse", type = "source") as well as pulling the tarball and running direclty through R CMD INSTALL after all other dependencies are installed with the same outcome.

The installation succeeds when installing directly through binary.
@dpastoor it sounds like you have ggplot2 loaded. Try installing in a fresh R session.

Is this a bad idea? Or is anyone developing this already?

In a meta-package inspired by the __tidyverse__, I'm drafting an install-helper (think `tidyverse::install_me()`) which goal is to avoid installing via DESCRIPTION > Imports and instead use something like the `please_install()` function that @hadley wrote to set-up his tidy-tools workshop.

Benefits of `install_me()` :

* installs directly from CRAN avoiding the `Error in unloadNamespace(package) : namespace ‘PKG’ is imported by ‘tidyverse’ so cannot be unloaded`.
* Catches the errors and throws more informative messages.
* Captures the output of  `intall.packages()` and shows progress, errors, warnings and messages as __testthat__ does during testing. This way users can focus on the important stuff.
@maurolepore we are working on this already; it's a lot of work to do correctly.

@hadley completely fresh session(s). I even worried that maybe the daily version of Rstudio was loading stuff so tried from both the terminal via `install.packages`, and finally, this even presents when installing via R CMD INSTALL on the command line after manually downloading and pointing to the tidyverse tarball
@hadley, great! It that work public? I'd love to follow that.

@dpastoor are you sure you're not loading packages in your `.Rprofile`? If so, try deleting your entire library.

@maurolepore yes, but it's not suitable for public consumption yet so we're not advertising it, and you'll need to find it yourself.

@hadley I think I'm tracking it down. It looks like it is an artifact somehow of in the tmp directory where the installation occurs, if tidyverse deps are present is causing this corruption

For example, given the following command:

```
R CMD INSTALL --build --install-tests --no-multiarch --with-keep.source --library=/var/folders/km/ljmnf0bx73l9m4zdygvb6q_80000gn/T/ /Users/devinp/go/src/github.com/dpastoor/rpackagemanager/integration_tests/testsets/pkgcache2/CRAN/src/tidyverse_1.2.1.tar.gz
```

if in `/var/folders/km/ljmnf0bx73l9m4zdygvb6q_80000gn/T/` there are still folders such as `tidyr` folder that contains an installed version of tidyr, 

```
* installing *source* package ‘tidyverse’ ...
** package ‘tidyverse’ successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked
** R
** inst
** byte-compile and prepare package for lazy loading
** help
*** installing help indices
*** copying figures
** building package indices
** installing vignettes
** testing if installed package can be loaded\nERROR: loading failed
* removing ‘/private/var/folders/km/ljmnf0bx73l9m4zdygvb6q_80000gn/T/tidyverse’" Error: package or namespace load failed for ‘tidyverse’:
 .onAttach failed in attachNamespace() for 'tidyverse', details:
  call: value[[3L]](cond)\n  error: Package ‘tidyr’ version 0.8.2 cannot be unloaded:
 Error in unloadNamespace(package) : namespace ‘tidyr’ is imported by ‘broom’, ‘tidyverse’ so cannot be unloaded
Error: loading failed
Execution halted
```

By clearing out the tmpdir and/or creating a nested subfolder that is empty, the error resolves, though I'm not entirely clear what is causing the conflict in the first place :-/

I was also able to reproduce this error on CentOS7 and was due to a bug inside my .Rprofile. Backstory: to reduce issues being unable to write to shared locations on the server I had placed the following code in my .Rprofile such that packages would be installed only into my home directory without R trying to update packages that existed in the shared parths (as that would result in a permissions error).

`assign(".lib.loc", Sys.getenv("R_LIBS_USER"), envir = environment(.libPaths))`

However, when using packrat, installing packages such as tidyverse which restart the rsession during installation then cause issues when packrat is installing the package into the project directory.

In my case wrapping the assignment in my .Rprofile in the following if statement solved the issue.
```
if (is.na(match("packrat", loadedNamespaces()))) {
  assign(".lib.loc", Sys.getenv("R_LIBS_USER"), envir = environment(.libPaths))
}
```

Had the very same error on my machine after it upgraded R from 3.5.2 to 3.5.3. This is with a project that uses packrat.

In my case it was resolved by removing a call to `.libPaths()` from my `.Rprofile` file.

    # ~/.Rprofile
    # .libPaths(c("/home/me/.R", .libPaths()))

(Might just as well have deleted the file.)
Will probably be fixed by #171


Installation failed when using the CRAN version:

```R

dir.create(tmp)
.libPaths(tmp)

install.packages("tidyverse", type = "source")
```

Font problems?

node.body: Any ideas @gaborcsardi?

Looks like a cli bug.

On 11 Nov 2017 15:03, "Hadley Wickham" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Any ideas @gaborcsardi <https://github.com/gaborcsardi>?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tidyverse/tidyverse/issues/87#issuecomment-343671120>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAoTQJu7jXWaKNfYwfp9rjwsd_EQd6gNks5s1bdWgaJpZM4QZ-yr>
> .
>

Interestingly `cli::symbol$tick` is displayed correctly...

```
cli::symbol$tick
[1] "√"
```

... and colored too

```
cat(crayon::green(cli::symbol$tick))
√
```

So I guess something must get broken 'down the line'

So I pinned that to:
- `cat(crayon::green(cli::symbol$tick)) ` works OK
- `message(crayon::green(cli::symbol$tick))` does not, and it is called by `msg()` within `tidyverse_attach()`.

IMHO must be something with `gettext` and message translation...
Oh, interesting. I was sure that it was just because of the Polish codepage. But looks like it is not only that.
That was my first guess too. Incidentally, I have the message translations switched off.

Just to add to this; We're "seeing" the `$tick` "properly", but it is angering pandoc when we call `library("tidyverse")` in a `knitr` context. That is, the output from `attach` is generating the tick signs, and a component of pandoc is not happy with them (Unicode in a UTF8 context) when it tries to generate LaTeX on the way to PDF.

We're trying to see if we can make changes to pandoc to accommodate the issue but... digging into pandoc issues has historically been about as fun as diving into a swimming pool filled only with masonry fragments and rebar. I don't know how attached (_ha!_) you are to the ticks and special x characters, but maybe keeping simple ascii tokens (+/-) would be more portable?

We also tried to suppress attachment output with `library("tidyverse", quietly=TRUE)` but the output was still generated; It would be handy if the `quietly` flag was detected there, though I'm not certain that's the intended role of that flag. Our other option is to attach tidyverse prior to knitting, or at least in a kintr block where the output isn't captured, but then we don't have the nice package manifest that it generates.

Thanks!
@maptracker See for some possible solutions.
I scooted my challenge with knitr into new issue #96

FWIW stack trace below. Seems related to https://github.com/tidyverse/tidyverse/issues/83 but unlike that issue it's not complaining about not finding a function (or is it)

```
       attr(package, "LibPath") <- which.lib.loc
       ns <- loadNamespace(package, lib.loc)
       env <- attachNamespace(ns, pos = pos, deps)
```

Hi Harrison, I'm not sure about the "unable to access index error you're getting but mine turned out to be an issue with the readr  file structure being locked. A previous installed that failed locked the folder from any further writing. The below code worked for me, good luck.

` #If "failed to create lock" is the returned error, install with the below code;`
`install.packages("readr", dependencies=TRUE, INSTALL_opts = c('--no-lock'))`
Hello Jim, thanks a TON! As for the "access index" part of the error, I had `setRepositories()` pointed incorectly when trying to troubleshoot the problem.
Haha, you're welcome. It was the same for me, I scratched my head for hours until I spotted failed to create lock was the key bit of information in the error.

You are always best of installing from a fresh R session with no packages loaded; unfortunately `install.packages()` almost-silently fails on windows when you have a binary package loaded in the current session.

``` r
x <- c("xyz","abc","def","ghi","abc")

stringr::str_order(x)
#> [1] 2 5 3 4 1

```

node.title: error namespace load failed for "tidyverse"

node.body:
Have you tried reinstalling and loading the [stringi](https://github.com/gagolews/stringi/blob/738f4b1ab5845ba2879f3d5fff2e60767ea691e5/NAMESPACE) package? All of these functions are from that package, which is imported by stringr (one of the tidyverse packages):
https://github.com/tidyverse/stringr/blob/master/NAMESPACE
In the event that you can't get stringi or stringr installed, you should file this issue in the stringr repo, since the tidyverse package is just a wrapper around its constituent packages and the changes would need to be addressed over there.

Hopefully this helps!

node.title: Error involving rvest and xml2

When happens if you try to install the packages individually?
(meaning rvest and xml2, not all of the tidyverse packages individually)

I assume you are talking about rvest and xml2 only.  They both fail.  Both are dependent on each other.  Dependency xml2 is not available for package rvest.

I have not tried installing individual tidyverse packages one by one yet.  I was hoping to avoid having to do that.

[rvest](https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rvest) depends on [xml2](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/xml2/index.html) (xml2 doesn't depend on rvest), if you're having trouble with your xml2 installation (which sounds likely), could you please file an issue in the [xml2](https://github.com/r-lib/xml2) repo? (I recommend searching the existing issues for your error message first, open or closed, as there tend to be common issues/solutions in there 👍).

Since the tidyverse package just wraps the component packages, I'm going to close this issue, as any related issues will be resolved in the individual package libraries!

node.title: arrange(., .by_group = TRUE) only sorting on first grouped variable

node.body:
Hi @steenharsted,

For future reference, since tidyverse (the package) is just a meta-package, this issue really belongs in the [dplyr](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr) repo (I've prefixed the functions used in your issue for clarity). 

However, I believe the issue here is just a matter of the defaults – dplyr [`arrange()`](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/arrange.html) sorts in _ascending_ order by default (this has been discussed, but it would break too much existing code to change it now https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1206#issuecomment-239848173). So, if you add `desc()` around your grouping variable, it should turn out as you would expect.

``` r
library(tidyverse)
df <- data.frame(
  animal = c("tiger", "cat", "dog", "dog", "cat", "tiger", "cat", "cat", "cat", "tiger", "tiger", "tiger"),
  zoo = c("NY", "PHI", "PHI", "NY", "NY", "PHI", "NY", "NY", "PHI", "PHI", "PHI", "NY"),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

df1 <- df %>% 
  dplyr::group_by(zoo, animal) %>% 
  dplyr::summarise(freq = n()) %>% 
  dplyr::arrange(freq, .by_group = TRUE)

df1
#> # A tibble: 6 x 3
#> # Groups:   zoo [2]
#>   zoo   animal  freq
#>   <chr> <chr>  <int>
#> 1 NY    dog        1
#> 2 NY    tiger      2
#> 3 NY    cat        3
#> 4 PHI   dog        1
#> 5 PHI   cat        2
#> 6 PHI   tiger      3

df2 <- df %>% 
  dplyr::group_by(zoo, animal) %>% 
  dplyr::summarise(freq = n()) %>% 
  dplyr::arrange(dplyr::desc(freq), .by_group = TRUE)

df2
#> # A tibble: 6 x 3
#> # Groups:   zoo [2]
#>   zoo   animal  freq
#>   <chr> <chr>  <int>
#> 1 NY    cat        3
#> 2 NY    tiger      2
#> 3 NY    dog        1
#> 4 PHI   tiger      3
#> 5 PHI   cat        2
#> 6 PHI   dog        1
```
Created on 2018-06-19 by the [reprex package](http://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.2.0).

Ever-clever @jennybc just pointed out that this is _actually_ a product of the fact that `summarize()` always strips off one layer of grouping! See this dplyr thread for details:
https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/3553

node.title: Warning message about integer overflow when loading tidyverse in a fresh R session

node.body:
Hmm— NAs produced by integer overflow usually refers to the attempt to coerce a value to an integer. Are you opening some sort of saved workspace? 
Have you recently updated the tidyverse package?
What happens if you load another package first? 
It makes more sense with `read_csv()` as, in so doing you're reading in values…

See https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr/issues/403 for an example, and/or this thread, [What is integer overflow in R and how can it happen?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8804779/what-is-integer-overflow-in-r-and-how-can-it-happen), on StackOverflow.

Since tidyverse is a meta-package, it seems unlikely that whatever is producing this is internal to the specific package. You might want to ask about this on [community.rstudio.com](https://community.rstudio.com/) (along with some of the answers to the questions I listed above) where more people can help you troubleshoot (and if it _does_ turn out to be a tidyverse package bug, we can address it with more information here).

Thanks for the quick reply.

Answering your questions:
1. I am never saving my workspace.
2. I do not remember when was the last time I've updated tidyverse.
3. Every single package I've tried, after opening RStudio, gives me the same warning. Therefore, I tend to think it is something related to the IDE--I've been running the 1.2.830 preview, but I've just seen there is a newer one. 

Thank you for the provided links. I had already been reading through them, but my case seemed very weird. 

Given the 3rd point above, feel free to close this issue. I will have yet another look on RStudio Community and, if the update to the latest RStudio preview does not fix this, open an issue in rstudio/rstudio.

> Given the 3rd point above, feel free to close this issue. 

Will do. Good luck!

FYI, updating to the latest RStudio preview version 1.2.907 fixed this.

@batpigandme thanks for the help!

node.title: library(tidyverse, quietly=TRUE, warn.conflicts=FALSE) isn't quiet and shows conflicts.

node.body: Yes, that makes sense! And, can confirm that I'm seeing the same thing with both dev and CRAN versions.

Hmm… I may have spoken too soon (see @hadley's comment in a closed issue, below)
https://github.com/tidyverse/tidyverse/issues/127#issuecomment-384474370

personally, I use 
```r
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidyverse))
```

But, per NEWS:

> You can now suppress this startup message by setting options(tidyverse.quiet = TRUE)

https://github.com/tidyverse/tidyverse/blame/master/NEWS.md#L32-L33
Okay, regarding `quietly=TRUE` but what about `warn.conflicts=FALSE`?

The conflicts message will go away in the next release since the tidyverse is going to attach conflicted.

The quietly argument `quietly` has much narrower scope than you might think. From the docs:

>  a logical. If TRUE, no message confirming package attaching is printed, and most often, no errors/warnings are printed if package attaching fails.

node.title: Trouble installing tidyverse on macOS 10.13.4 (High Sierra) - solved by xcode-select --install

node.body:
>Uninstall all versions of R and RStudio from MacBook Air.
> ...
> Install RStudio 1.1.456.
> which r from command line finds nothing (so I believe there are no conflicting version of R in play).

I realize this sounds absurd, but I thought you had to install R at some point before installing RStudio.

That aside, the libxml2 problem is definitely one I've run into before, though.  Do you run into the same problem trying to install [xml2](https://github.com/r-lib/xml2) in a empty R installation? Just trying to figure out if it's localised to the tidyverse meta-package (this), or if it has something to do with the xml2 dependency outside of tidyverse.

There have been a few threads on community with xml2 installation troubles, e.g.
* https://community.rstudio.com/t/xml2-package-installation-issues-pkg-config-path-help/10319/3?u=mara
* https://community.rstudio.com/t/download-data-from-website-into-rstudio/2345/19?u=mara

1. I thought I had to install R before RStudio, but apparently that's not (or no longer?) true. `which r` on my Mac still comes up empty - how do I check the path to the R executable from within RStudio?
2. Just got my company laptop, so I'll try installing there and see what happens - if I understand correctly, I should `brew install r` and then run R from the command line and run `install.package('xml2')` ?
Thanks!

Within R itself, for example from the R Console inside RStudio, `R.home()` and `Sys.which("R")` will give you information on

  * the full path to your R installation
  * the path to the `R` executable

``` r
R.home()
#> [1] "/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Resources"
Sys.which("R")
#>                  R 
#> "/usr/local/bin/R"
```

These instructions on running multiple versions of R (I realize that's not your problem) might also give helpful ideas for understanding where you are vs. need to be.

https://support.rstudio.com/hc/en-us/articles/200486138-Changing-R-versions-for-RStudio-desktop

I would highly recommend using the precompiled binary from CRAN for your OS (sound like macOS) instead of installing R with homebrew.

https://cloud.r-project.org

To be clear, I also use home-brew for all sorts of things. But I do not use it to install R itself.

1. `R.home()` reports `/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Resources`, which isn't in my `PATH` - I must have installed R via the r-project.org installer at some point (?).
2. Installing RStudio on my new company laptop -> can't find R, so @batpigandme was right - it needs separate installation.

For posterity, I ran into the same issue and by sheer luck I was sitting with @jimhester and figured out the source of my problem quickly. So for future people stumbling upon this thread, if you are using a new computer with High Sierra or Mojave and would like to install R fresh, you'll likely run into this same error as @gvwilson if you used Homebrew `brew` to install R as in:

`$ brew install r`

I did this via a Homebrew Brewfile, and it was the source of my `xml2` problem. So first I undid that install using:

`$ brew uninstall r`

This means I was OK with torching all my installed packages, because I was on a new computer I was OK with this!

Then I used Homebrew to install the `r-app` via cask:

`$ brew cask install r-app`

After doing that, I was able to install the `tidyverse` package (and all my other packages) without problems.

My updated Brewfile then looked like this:

```
tap 'homebrew/cask'
cask 'r-app'
```

I have also found that if you are using anaconda it will screw up libxml2 (and occasionally some other things) for R. In the past I was able to get around this with `$ conda deactivate` then `R> install.packages() that need XML2` then `$ conda activate base` (or whatever your env of choice is). I also just happened upon the suggestion @apreshill mentioned, and it helps a lot with problems like this, because now you can install the precompiled package binaries from CRAN instead of having to compile them yourself.
I think the basic advice is __NEVER INSTALL R FROM BREW__ (unless you really know what you are doing).

> I have also found that if you are using anaconda it will screw up libxml2 (and occasionally some other things) for R. In the past I was able to get around this with `$ conda deactivate` then `R> install.packages() that need XML2` then `$ conda activate base` (or whatever your env of choice is). I also just happened upon the suggestion @apreshill mentioned, and it helps a lot with problems like this, because now you can install the precompiled package binaries from CRAN instead of having to compile them yourself.
Thank you very much, I've never tough about conda screw up..
This stackoverflow answer worked for me: https://stackoverflow.com/a/50252325
