node.title: tidyverse attaches its children packages at `pos=2`

node.body: Why does this matter?

In my case I want to evaluate things in the `something` environment, and I want to be able to use `tidyverse` functions in this environment after calling `library(tidyverse, pos = 3)`, which is currently not possible. As for other use cases I think it would matter whenever the `pos` argument is relevant.

Another use case that comes to my mind, that would be more common, is if I want to load `tidyverse` and be sure not to override some other package's functions that I need to makes sure not to break scripts that I wrote without using `::`.
This doesn't seem terribly important to me, so I'd recommend simply attaching the packages individually.

This is not possible in my case, I won't decide what packages the user attaches.

In my opinion the fact that attaching packages separately is not equivalent to attaching `tidyverse` is counter intuitive.

Meanwhile I found a fix for my own case and posted it as an answer.
Writing code that assumes an environment will be attached in a specific place in the search list is fragile, and seems unlikely to be a productive approach.

node.title: More question than issue: structuring a metapackage

node.body: I think this is a better fit for the package development section of https://community.rstudio.com/c/package-development. Would you like to take discussion there?
Sure, thanks (I was in your Seattle WTF workshop btw).
Ah, yes! I remember 🙂

@martinamorris, 

Thanks for bringing this up. You are not alone in finding this confusing:

> The package namespace (as recorded in the NAMESPACE file) is one of the more confusing parts of building a package

-- [R Packages / NAMESPACE](http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/namespace.html)

Jenny's suggestion is great. Here are some pointers that might help you prepare to lead the discussion:

* > It really depends on how you expect your package to be used. If it is a 'true' meta-package and really has no additional functionality itself I think just using Depends is the best option, so users can just `install.packages("metapackage"); library(metapackage)` and have all the child packages attached.

--  Jim Hester 

* > Listing a package in either Depends or Imports ensures that it’s installed when needed. [W]here Imports just loads the package, Depends attaches it. There are no other differences. 

-- [R Packages / NAMESPACE](http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/namespace.html)

It sounds like the dependencies weren't installed (clearly), but in order to help you troubleshoot, basic system information, and full error messages will be helpful.

node.title: tidyverse_rlang error

node.body:
Since the tidyverse is a meta package, it's best to file issues in the specific package that's resulting in the error. I'm happy to move it for you, but in order to get this sorted, we'll need some more information. 

Could you please turn this into a self-contained [reprex](http://reprex.tidyverse.org/) (short for minimal **repr**oducible **ex**ample)? It will help us help you if we can be sure we're all working with/looking at the same stuff.

If you've never heard of a reprex before, you might want to start by reading the tidyverse.org [help page](https://www.tidyverse.org/help/).

You can install reprex by running (you may already have it, though, if you have the tidyverse package installed):
```r
install.packages("reprex")
```

Thanks
You need to update dplyr. See https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/3941

node.title: pluck_impl object not found

node.body:
Hi Tobias,

Is this a fresh installation that you can't load in a new session of R? Have you tried reinstalling?
This sort of question might be a better fit for https://community.rstudio.com until we can determine whether or not it's a bug in the package itself, or if there's something funky going on with your installation. If it's a bug, I'll happily re-open.

Thanks,

Mara

I have the same problem.   Used RStudio to do a new install of tidyverse,  then restarted RStudio.  Called library(tidyverse) and got the following:

Error : .onAttach failed in attachNamespace() for 'tidyverse', details:
  call: pluck(x, 1, .default = NULL)
  error: object 'pluck_impl' not found
Error: package or namespace load failed for ‘tidyverse’
Are you on Windows @GGAnderson?
Your initial problem smells like a corrupt/partial install, so glad to hear that a fresh installation of tidyverse (?) sorted you out. I think the "anomalies" you note are harmless.

No, the fresh installs do not sort it out.  Here's the dialog.
```
> install.packages("tidyverse")
Installing package into ‘C:/Users/GGAnderson/Documents/R/win-library/3.3’
(as ‘lib’ is unspecified)
trying URL 'https://cran.rstudio.com/bin/windows/contrib/3.3/tidyverse_1.2.1.zip'
Content type 'application/zip' length 82085 bytes (80 KB)
downloaded 80 KB

package ‘tidyverse’ successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked

The downloaded binary packages are in
	C:\Users\Public\Documents\Wondershare\CreatorTemp\RtmpMTNjCm\downloaded_packages
> library(tidyverse)
-- Attaching packages --------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.2.1 --
v ggplot2 3.1.0     v dplyr   0.7.8
v tidyr   0.8.2     v stringr 1.3.1
v ggplot2 3.1.0     v forcats 0.3.0
Error : .onAttach failed in attachNamespace() for 'tidyverse', details:
  call: pluck(x, 1, .default = NULL)
  error: object 'pluck_impl' not found
Error: package or namespace load failed for ‘tidyverse’
```

Each of the individual libraries load separately, but tidyverse does not.

@jennybc  if both Tobias and I are getting the exact same error message with fresh installs (and repeat installs) within 6 days of each other,  it would seem to be a bug in the tidyverse 1.2.1 package for windows.    Perhaps we should remove and try to install from source?

My theories still revolve around a corrupt/partial installation. In this case, probably of purrr? `install.packages()` often misbehaves on Windows if you are trying to install a package that is currently in use.

I recommend you do something like this (but for purrr, as opposed to rlang):
https://community.rstudio.com/t/difficulty-installing-dev-version-of-ggplot2-due-to-rlang-is-list-not-being-found/8169/9

I'm going to let @batpigandme take it from here, because I suspect she is the most familiar with the typical symptoms and recommended cure.

Thanks, @jennybc     I don't think the problem is at the individual library level -  all including purrr load fine independently.   My code is using purrr without problem.

The error occurs ONLY when loading tidyverse.     Let me just say that I am a very big fan of the entire collection - these are THE powertools for serious R data work in the modern era.   Kudos to each and every one of the coders and curators contributing to the tidyverse collection.
It is possible that you never call `pluck()` but it is called when the tidyverse package itself is attached.

Hi @GGAnderson,

Sorry for the delay, I've been away. So, as Jenny mentioned, this can happen with partial installs. Can you try removing (`remove.packages()`) purrr and then reinstalling it and see what happens? I understand that the problem is occurring when you are loading the tidyverse package, but it's still likely that the problem occurs when `pluck()` is called (and `pluck()` is in purrr).

Thanks.

Hi @batpigandme    Thank you for this tip.   You and @jennybc were exactly right. 

I ran install.packages() purr,  followed by a tidyverse install- and the problem is now corrected.    So if others have the same problem, just install purrr first, separately.      Thank you!

Hi, I  reinstalled also a fresh instance and now it works. I run an automated script and purr is surely installed first...

Thanks a lot and best wishes
Tobias

Great! :-)
We are all here to help each other  -- no time wasted at all.

node.title: Remove messages when loading tidyverse

node.body: Given many users operate outside of Rmd, I think it would be dangerous to suppress all warnings regarding conflicts by default. The tidyverse package neatens this up, but the behaviour is standard for attaching packages in R.
@mloop You might like having a standard "setup chunk", possibly stored as an RStudio snippet, if you use RStudio. And you could put `options(tidyverse.quiet = TRUE)` in it.
Thanks for the suggestion @jennybc, and I agree @batpigandme that it is standard output and should not be treated differently. Thanks for the feedback.

This only became an issue for me _after_ I installed R 3.6.0

I also noticed that I receive 'lazy-loading' file errors when trying to update the tibble package from source w R-3.5.3 
Same as @kgmccann I also have both R-3.5.3 and R-3.6.0 installed next to each other on my machine; I might also add that the installation directory is C:\R\R.version and not C:\Program Files … 
Installing from source and starting eg tibble is no problem under R-3.6.0 
All of the above actions are being executed in RStudio 1.2.1335
Same issue with me, only occurs after I install R-3.6.0.
I am currently experiencing the same issue. I installed 3.6.0 so I could run tree package and then suddenly I lose tidyverse packages and no possibility to install them.
Did you reinstall all packages for 3.6, or did you try and use your old R 3.5 packages?
I updated old ones.

I am having the same problem even after having reinstalled all the packages for 3.6. This doesn't happen when I run R locally on my mac but if I send in scripts to my job's linux based computing cluster I get this error.

I am almost 100% certain this is due to having a mix of packages for R 3.5 and 3.6 installed in the same library:

```R
# In R 3.5
env <- asNamespace("MASS")
head(getNamespaceInfo(env, "S3methods"))
#>      [,1]      [,2]        [,3]             
#> [1,] "["       "fractions" "[.fractions"    
#> [2,] "[<-"     "fractions" "[<-.fractions"  
#> [3,] "addterm" "default"   "addterm.default"
#> [4,] "addterm" "glm"       "addterm.glm"    
#> [5,] "addterm" "lm"        "addterm.lm"     
#> [6,] "addterm" "mlm"       "addterm.mlm"

# In R 3.6
env <- asNamespace("MASS")
head(getNamespaceInfo(env, "S3methods"))
#>      [,1]      [,2]        [,3]              [,4]
#> [1,] "["       "fractions" "[.fractions"     NA  
#> [2,] "[<-"     "fractions" "[<-.fractions"   NA  
#> [3,] "addterm" "default"   "addterm.default" NA  
#> [4,] "addterm" "glm"       "addterm.glm"     NA  
#> [5,] "addterm" "lm"        "addterm.lm"      NA  
#> [6,] "addterm" "mlm"       "addterm.mlm"     NA  
```

The chances are that some time in the distant past you have followed some advice that means that you don't have to re-install packages when you re-install R. Unfortunately the advice you followed is bad, because it leads to situations exactly like this.

You may be able to fix the problem by forcing a re-install of all packages:

```R
update.packages(ask = FALSE, checkBuilt = TRUE)
```

You **must** use `checkBuilt = TRUE` in order for this to work.

This is not a tidyverse issue, so I'm going to close it, but feel free to continue discussion here.

Thanks!

node.title: >R-3.5.3 on WIN10 Pro - Error: package or namespace load failed for '...' in rbind(info, getNamespaceInfo(env, "S3methods")): number of columns of matrices must match (see arg 2)

node.body:
I solved it the hard way 
I removed all packages in my 3.5. pkg lib and reinstalled them via 
```
ip <- as.data.frame(installed.packages(lib.loc = .libPaths()[1]), 
                    stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
head(ip)
str(ip)
path.lib <- unique(ip$LibPath)

# create a vector with all the names of the packages you want to remove
pkgs.to.remove <- ip[,1]
head(pkgs.to.remove)
str(pkgs.to.remove)

sapply(pkgs.to.remove, remove.packages, lib = path.lib)
sapply(pkgs.to.remove, install.packages, lib = path.lib)
```

node.title: Filter operation doesn't work if variable name intersects with column name

node.body:
This issue would be better filed in the repository for the dplyr package, which is where `filter()` comes from. This repository is for the tidyverse meta-package, which really doesn't hold any "smarts" *per se*.

But to answer your question, you can use the `{{ }}` "embracing" or "curly curly" syntax in this case:

``` r
library(tidyverse)

(df <- tibble(
  x = 1:3,
  y = letters[x]
))
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>       x y    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     1 a    
#> 2     2 b    
#> 3     3 c

df %>% filter(y == "b")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x y    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     2 b

z <- "b"
df %>% filter(y == z)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x y    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     2 b
df %>% filter(y == {{ z }})
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x y    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     2 b

y <- "b"
df %>% filter(y == {{ y }})
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#>       x y    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     2 b
```

<sup>Created on 2019-10-04 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0.9000)</sup>
Thanks for the quick response. I did not know about the `{{ }}` notation. Good to know! I will migrate this issue over to `dplyr`. Thanks again.
For reference, I've reposted this at https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4578
